Ottawa, August 11, 1939.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 8th instant, in which you intimate that it is your intention to have the necessary repairs undertaken at the Indian day school on the Shubenacadie reserve by the Indians and by yourself.

May I point out to you the urgency of this matter. It is of the utmost importance that this school re-open on September 5. The teacher who will conduct the school has been engaged by the Department and will report for duty on that date.

The necessary action to secure the seats requested by you will be taken here and delivery will be made in due course.

You are authorized, therefore, to proceed with the other additional repairs. If you find it impossible to have a table for the teacher made on the reserve, you should purchase one and have it installed at once.

Your only responsibility in this matter is to see that the repairs are undertaken and completed and the table and desks installed. Indian day schools are conducted by the Department from Ottawa. No provision is made in the Indian Act for the election of trustees to administer such schools. It is just possible that a caretaker may be required, but this is a matter that can be discussed with the teacher and the request sent forward later.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. S. Robb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Shubenacadie, N. S.

Ottawa,
September 26, 1939.

EX'D.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 22nd instant requesting 8 additional desks please let me know the size of desks which you require and the number of each size. For your information I may say that size No. 1 is intended for children 16 to 20, size No. 2 for children 12 to 16, size No. 3 for children 10 to 12, size No. 4 for children 8 to 10 and size No. 5 for children 5 to 8.

In connection with the appointment of a caretaker the Indian Agent should write to the Department stating who he considers should be employed for this work and the matter will then receive further consideration. You will be advised under separate cover regarding the books which you mention are necessary.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Miss Elsie Charles,
Teacher,
Indian Day School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
The Indian Agent is Mr. Robbs, and I find him very slow. I am supposed to go to him for my school supplies but I have found it necessary to order my own things. We are still without sufficient seating, books, maps, but we shall have them soon now.

There are about (thirty) twenty-five families here. We have a church near the school, and services once a month. I am (af) about five miles from Father Mackey.

Hoping you are enjoying perfect health, I am

Very sincerely yours,

Elsie Charles.
Shubenacadie, N.S.
Sept. 22, 1934

Mr. G. H. Cann,
Yarmouth North, N.S.

Dear Mr. Cann:

I have just finished my third week's teaching twenty-eight of the loveliest group of children I have ever met. They are wonderful! Each one is so eager to learn that it makes it a real pleasure to teach them.

Our school has been newly repaired but is still in need of many conveniences. However, I am working for a good deal and must go slowly. There are too many against this reservation having a school because of the larger school of Father MacKay's, therefore necessitating us to move slowly but surely.
Mr. Skelley,

Shubenacadie, N.S.
October 16, 1934

The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,

Dear Mr. Phelan,

I am forwarding the bill for fifteen yards of twill purchased for the use of the pupils of the Shubenacadie Indian Day School.

Our local Agent, Mr. Robb, had already purchased tin cups, but I had these exchanged at my own expense (and) for granite cups. The bill for the "tin" cups has already been forwarded to you.

The supply of books has arrived and my pupils are very interested in all we are doing for them.

I again mentioned caretaker to our agent, and "Miss Elizabeth Marr, Shubenacadie," has been
engaged for this position.

A second-hand teacher's desk has been supplied. (It is yet unfainted) also a second-hand table.

The question has arisen as to whom is to supply our wood or coal. Our local agent wants the Indian people to supply the school with wood, but I have been two weeks now waiting for a supply to come in, and none has come yet. Each seems to be waiting for someone else. If some one person were appointed to supply the wood for the school we could be dependent on him, as it is we are depending on everyone, and nothing is done.

Kindly advise as soon as possible what I can do towards this matter.

Mr. Dobbs has also promised to have our yard cleaned. I would have regarded this as an outdoor project for my pupils, if it were
not for the condition of the outside "toilets" that have been used and abandoned by the family who formerly occupied the school-house. However, this is not a child's work, so I cannot regard it as an outdoor project; therefore the condition of our school yard is very unsanitary and would surely be condemned if certain members of the Board of Health were to visit us. Kindly advise what further step I may take.

I would also like a copy of the list of books supplied by the Department for children in grades zero, three, five, six, seven and nine.

I shall send the "return" for September as soon as I receive the materials you are sending, but in the meantime, I would like to say I love my work and my pupils are doing nicely. I have a
wonderful group of boys and girls. Hoping their progress will continue and that their present standing will be satisfactory to you. I am

Sincerely yours,

Elgie Charles.
Ottawa,
October 21, 1939.

Dear Miss Charles:

I find it necessary to return the account which you forwarded covering the cost of the towelling purchased for the Shubenacadie day school. You should certify on the account that it is correct and that you have received the goods and sign all three copies.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Miss Elsie Charles,
Teacher,
Indian Day School,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
Ottawa,
October 21, 1939.

Dear Sir:

The Department is informed by the teacher of the Shubenacadie Indian day school that no wood has yet been supplied to the school. It was our understanding when the school was established that the Indians would supply the wood. Please make immediate arrangements for one or more Indians to supply the wood required for this school, without charge to the Department, at the earliest possible date.

I am also informed that Miss Elizabeth Marr has been appointed janitor at this school. Please state if she is an Indian and where she resides. You should also state on what date she begins duties as janitor.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. J. S. Robb,
Indian Agent,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the voucher which you submitted in favour of A.J. Reid & Sons in connection with the expenditure at the Shubenacadie day school it is noted that there is included an item for a bed spring and mattress. No authority was given for the purchase of these two articles and consequently payment is not being made for them.

I am returning the attached voucher which includes an item of $2.25 for repairing stove oven for John Knockwood. If you were authorized to have Knockwood's stove repaired you should submit a special voucher for this and a separate voucher for the articles purchased for the school at a cost of $5.45.

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Proposed new day schools to be erected at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni in the Province of Nova Scotia during 1943.

Provision is included in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1943-44 for an amount of $55,000.00 for the erection of a school, a principal's residence and a teachers' residence at each of the above two reserves.

The classroom buildings should be similar to that known as the St. Catherine's Indian Day School in the Cowichan Agency. The plans of this building should be followed with the following changes:

1. Double doors should be provided from the outside to the general workshop entrance to the latter to be by ramp. A railing should be provided around the exterior entrance to the general workshop.

2. Double doors should be provided between the general workshop and the sewing room, also between the sewing room and the kitchen. This will involve enlarging the passageway.

3. Extra flues should be placed in the chimney to provide for two kitchen ranges.

4. The window in the fuel room is considered unnecessary and the fuel room should be enlarged to a size 13'3" x 11'.

Memorandum:

Re: Centralization of Indian Agencies and Building Programs, Maritime Provinces

In accordance with the request from Dr. McGill in his memorandum to you of November 16th, and your notation thereon dated November 19th, 1942, regarding an inspection of suggested sites for Agency buildings in connection with the above, arrangements were made to have our Architect accompany Mr. W. S. Arneil, Acting Inspector of Indian Agencies in the Maritime Provinces, on an inspection trip which began on November 23rd, 1942, and occupied seventeen days. Mr. Gremarty, of the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch, had also been authorized by the Department to accompany Mr. Arneil and Mr. Buck.

Our Architect now reports as follows:

The Indian Affairs Branch has already begun action in centralizing the Indian population now occupying twenty-three separate reserves in Nova Scotia and Prince Edward Island on three existing reserves, the areas of which have recently been considerably increased by the purchase and expropriation of adjacent territory.

Each of these enlarged reserves will constitute an Agency, and on completion of the scheme, approximately one thousand Indians, from six existing reserves in Cape Breton Island, will be settled on the Escasoni Reserve. The same number from twelve other existing reserves in Nova Scotia will be accommodated on the Shubenacadie Reserve. The Indians now occupying five reserves on Prince Edward Island will be centralized on Lennox Island Reserve, and will number approximately two hundred and seventy-five persons.

The Indian Affairs Branch proposes, during the fiscal year of 1943-44, to erect at Shubenacadie and Escasoni, a day school with four class-rooms, manual-training room and domestic-science room, as well as a residence for the Priest-Principal, a residence to accommodate at least five teachers, and a combined office and storehouse for the Indian Agent. To this group there may in the future be added a Medical Officer's residence, and a residence for the Indian Agent.

At Lennox Island, P.E.I., it is proposed to build during the 1943-44 fiscal year, an Indian Agent's residence only, and at a later date, as funds become available, a combined office and storehouse, a two-room day school, and other buildings.

Other installations common to all sites will be water supply systems, septic tanks and sewage disposal beds.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,

Housing accommodation, without water supply, lighting or plumbing, is being provided for the increased population by the Indian Affairs Branch. Heads of families are being provided with building materials without expense, and they, with other unemployed Indians, are being encouraged to undertake work on these buildings, for which services they will be paid 30¢ per hour.

In this connection a considerable number of window frames and sash, as well as other materials surplus to their own requirements, were being disposed of by the R. A. F. Works and Buildings Division at Moncton, N. B., and Mr. Buck, before leaving Ottawa, was authorized to stop off with Mr. Arneil, with a view to determining whether any of the materials could be utilized in the Indian housing programme. It was found that the frames and sash were suitable for Indian Affairs' use, and that other materials, including plaster board and building paper, which would also be of value, were available. It is understood that the Indian Affairs Branch are arranging to obtain quantities of the materials inspected, through Departmental channels.

The inspection of materials at Moncton was completed on November 25th, and the party proceeded to Truro that evening, and thence to Shubenacadie, where the Department maintains an Indian Residential School at present occupied by 14 pupils, under the administration of the Principal, Rev. Father Mackey.

The Indian Affairs Branch had authorized Mr. Arneil to engage local surveyors for the purpose of obtaining spot levels, contours and other topographical features of the sites, and before leaving Truro arrangements were completed to have Mr. Howard Murray, of Earlton, N. S., carry out this work at Shubenacadie. Mr. Murray, Provincial Land Surveyor, was unable to visit the site with the Departmental officers. He stated that an uncompleted assignment from the Department of National Defence demanded his immediate attention. He was willing, however, to undertake and complete the work as described by Mr. Buck, beginning on November 30th, and completing his survey plan so that the data would be available for use by this Service upon the return of our Architect to Ottawa.

To this end, while carrying out the inspection of the site, detailed instructions regarding the area affected and the information required, were furnished to the Indian Agent, Mr. H. C. Rice, for Murray's guidance.

It was learned that on a previous visit to the reserve, which is approximately three miles from the Village of Shubenacadie, Indian Affairs officers had tentatively selected two alternative sites for an Agency building group, one being in the neighbourhood of the existing church and one-room day school, the second being approximately one-half mile directly south of the first.

The area....
The area is served by one of a series of Indian gravelled roads on the reserve, and a road allowance has already been cleared for another which will connect up two of the most travelled of the existing roads and will pass through the centre of the site. At present the connection between the gravelled road referred to, and the allowance for the new road, is a wagon trail which will be improved to become part of the new road on completion.

After viewing the available sites, Mr. Buck chose the southerly as being the better location for the proposed group of buildings. This site, which consists of approximately 65 acres of crown land, is approached from the north over the wagon trail already mentioned, at a gentle incline which flattens out in the proposed building area. The ground falls rapidly away from the site on its south, east and west boundaries, providing good natural drainage and making available several suitable locations for sewage disposal beds.

The soil in the neighbourhood appears to consist of a top covering of sandy loam, over a subsoil of sand and gravel. No rocks or large boulders were observed.

While the location of buildings on the site cannot be definitely established until the topographical plan is received and studied, it is felt that the soil composition may be considered uniform, and not likely to produce structural difficulties.

It would be possible to provide a water supply from streams in the vicinity; but it is anticipated that when the increased Indian population is settled on the reserve, the danger of water contamination will always be present. It is felt that investigation should be carried out to determine the feasibility of furnishing a water supply from drilled wells.

The only power transmission line close to the reserve terminates at the Village limits of Shubenacadie. As it is hoped to provide current for lighting in all buildings except the day-school, and for the operation of mechanical services in the Agency grounds, it will be necessary to determine the most economical method of making electric current available.

The Shubenacadie Agent of the Avon River Power Company was contacted, but since the Company is a subsidiary of the Nova Scotia Light and Power Company Limited of Halifax, this officer advised that any enquiries regarding extension of service must be directed to the Company's head office. It was understood from the Power Company's Agent, that an extension of the existing service to serve the proposed buildings on the reserve, under present conditions, would be difficult to obtain.

The inspection of Shubenacadie was completed on November 28th, and on that evening the party proceeded to Sydney, Cape Breton.

Mr. Cromarty had arranged with the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch to have Mr. MacMillan, Superintendent of the Cape Breton Highlands National Park, and a Departmental car available for the use of the inspecting party in travelling between Sydney and the Escasoni Reserve, which is situated on the north shore of East Bay, Bras D'Or Lake, approximately 33 miles south west of Sydney.
The site which had been tentatively selected by Indian Affairs officers on a previous occasion, overlooks East Bay in all directions, and possesses great scenic beauty. Its position with regard to the Indian settlement scheme now under way, and to the Roman Catholic chapel and cemetery, both of which are within the area, appears to establish it as the logical location for the proposed building group.

The site is reached over a gravel road, which branches off Provincial Highway No. 4 at the eastern end of East Bay. It occupies about seven acres of cleared land on the top, as well as the southerly and westerly slopes of a hill rising rather sharply to a flat area approximately 50 ft. above the roadway. The northerly and easterly slopes of the hill fall steeply towards small ravines, and are uncleared.

In the vicinity of the suggested site, the existing 60 ft. road allowance consists of a side hill cut, approximately 500 yards long, which leaves the northerly edge of the cutting between 10 and 15 ft. above the roadway, while from the southerly limit of the road allowance a scrub covered slope descends rapidly to a large area of tidal flat.

At the time of the inspection, the ground was covered with snow from six to eight inches deep, with drifts to a greater depth in places. Consequently no test pits were dug to determine soil characteristics where the proposed buildings were likely to be placed. Existing excavation for an earth cellar within an unused concrete foundation on the site, however, indicated at that point a top soil of sandy loam containing light clay and gravel to a depth of approximately five feet, the maximum depth observed. No rock outcroppings were visible anywhere on the site, and it could be assumed that the characteristics described are uniform. There should be no difficulty in locating septic tanks or sewage disposal beds.

It appeared possible that water might be supplied to the site from a stream at the toe of the westerly slope; but under the prevailing conditions it could not be determined that permanent volume was available. It is considered advisable to investigate whether water might be obtained from drilled wells before deciding to make use of the stream. However, attention to this point under more favourable weather conditions is suggested.

Power facilities do not exist at Escasoni, and to provide current for lighting and the operation of mechanical services, the necessary equipment must be provided by the Indian Affairs Branch.

Before work on the building programme can be started, it will be necessary to provide the site with a service road for the use of the Contractor during construction operations, and later to serve the various units of the building group, and from data obtained a site plan will be prepared from which it will be possible to determine the work involved on this feature, and to estimate its cost.

Owing to the lack of topographical data, no previous technical consideration of the site had been possible, and to obtain information for our use it was necessary, as at Shubenacadie, to engage a local Surveyor, Mr. Arneil, on the authority of his Director,...
Director, made necessary investigations to this end, and the services of Mr. M. McMullen, a Provincial Land Surveyor of Nova Scotia, were obtained. Mr. McMullen was taken over the site and our requirements were outlined in detail. Although he was to report in ten days for service in the army, Mr. McMullen was able to obtain spot levels on a 50 ft. by 50 ft. grid, establish contours at 5 ft. vertical intervals, complete his field notes and forward a plan to Ottawa, by the time our officers returned.

While it would be desirable to carry out building operations on a more level site, no alternative area sufficiently large for the purpose is available, unless purchase or expropriation of additional land is arranged, and it is understood that the Indian Affairs Branch are not likely to take such further action.

The inspection of Escasoni Reserve was completed on December 2nd, and the party left Sydney, N. S., for Borden, P. E. I., that evening.

Mr. Cromarty had arranged with the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch to have Mr. E. Smith, Superintendent of Prince Edward Island National Park, available with a Departmental car for the transportation of the party to and from Lennox Island. It had also been arranged that Mr. Smith would obtain any topographical data our Architect required on the site of the proposed agency. Mr. Smith met the party on the evening of December 3rd at Borden as arranged, and drove them to Summerside.

Lennox Island is approximately 30 miles by road from Summerside, and lies about one mile off shore in Malpeque Bay, between Hog Island and the mainland.

On the morning of December 4th the party began their trip from Summerside, but owing to snow blocked roads were forced to return, and later the same day proceeded to Indian Agent Daly's office in Charlottetown. It is understood, however, that the Lands, Parks and Forests Branch are agreeable to making the services of Mr. Smith available for the preparation of whatever topographical data this Service requires, when weather conditions are more favourable.

On the evening of December 4th, Indian Agent Rice contacted Mr. Buck at Charlottetown by long distance telephone from Shubenacadie, and advised that he had been notified by Mr. Murray, The Surveyor who had been engaged for work on the selected site there, that, anticipating a further assignment from the Department of National Defence, he was not disposed to carry out the duties he had arranged with Mr. Buck to undertake. Indian Agent Rice advised that he had attempted to locate a Surveyor, but had found none available. Our Architect considered it advisable to contact a definite source of information regarding the services of a qualified Surveyor, and instead of accompanying Mr. Arnell and Mr. Cromarty back to Ottawa, arranged to meet Mr. Rice, at the Provincial Department of Highways in Halifax, on the morning of December 7th. He was able to interview Mr. Bellevue, Chief Engineer of the Department, and his Senior Office Engineer, Mr. Kenneth MacKenzie, who very kindly provided a list of names of Surveyors they were prepared to recommend.

(over)
Considerable difficulty was encountered in locating a Surveyor who was free to undertake our work; but contact was eventually made with one of the recommended parties, - Mr. R. W. McKenzie, D.L.S., of Enfield, N.S. Mr. McKenzie accompanied the Indian Agent and our Architect to Shubenacadie, was taken over the site, and agreed to begin work as required on December 10th. While more snow had fallen, and further frost penetration was evident, it should have been possible to obtain the information we required without too great difficulty.

After completing arrangements with Mr. McKenzie, Mr. Buck returned to Ottawa on December 10th. However, in a letter dated December 19th last, Indian Agent Rice advised us that Mr. McKenzie has been prevented by illness from commencing work, but that he anticipates the topographical data would be undertaken very shortly. It will be realized, however, that if severe weather conditions have set in, it is not unlikely the Surveyor's work will have to be postponed until the Spring.

While in the Maritimes Mr. Buck interviewed the following Contractors regarding the building situation there:

J. H. Kenney, General Contractor, Truro and Halifax, N.S.
The J. W. Stevens Co. Ltd., Sydney, Cape Breton, N.S.
H. J. Phillips, General Contractor, Charlottetown, P.E.I.

Each of these firms has at different periods carried out work for this Service satisfactorily, and all are at present engaged on some type of construction work for the Dominion Government in connection with National Defence Projects. These Contractors stand unanimously that they were experiencing great difficulty in obtaining materials and labour, and under existing circumstances can give no assurance that any work they undertake could be completed within a time limit, or that they would be able to adhere strictly to specified materials or equipment.

The experience of these firms confirms the opinion of this Service, that even if the Department is granted a licence by the Controller of Construction, authorizing building operations, we must be prepared for delays and possible substitutions in materials and equipment, with consequent increases in cost, none of which can be anticipated.

Further memoranda dealing with the building programme, funds provided, approval of sketches, working drawings and other related items, will be forwarded for your information as our work on these projects develops.

Chief Engineer.

Ottawa, August 11, 1943.

Mr. H. C. Rice, Indian Agent, Shubenacadie, N. S.

Tenders received by the Surveys and Engineering Branch for the construction of an Indian day school, a teacher's residence, a residence for a principal and an office building at Shubenacadie indicate that the cost of these buildings - should we proceed with their construction at this time - would be approximately three times greater than the amount provided in the 1942-43 estimates. In view of this fact, it will not be possible to proceed with our building program on your reserve at any time during the present fiscal year.

We are naturally anxious to do everything humanly possible to encourage Indian families, particularly families the members of which are not gainfully employed, to establish themselves at Shubenacadie. It is just possible that our failure to build a day school this year may retard to some extent the movement of Indian families to the reserve. We are anxious, therefore, that you should undertake, in co-operation with Father Mackey, a survey of the educational facilities available with the object of utilizing these to the fullest possible advantage.

We have in mind the organization of a class of day school pupils at Shubenacadie. Should this be at all practicable, transportation of course would have to be provided. Accommodation in the adjoining public school, where a small group of Indian children might be provided with instruction, should also be considered. An inexpensive addition, under the supervision of Mr. Robb, might be built to the Indian day school on the reserve.

We deeply regret our inability to proceed with the regular program of centralization, particularly the building program, and our failure to do so is likely to add to your burdens as agent. Is it your opinion that a temporary, inexpensive office building should be constructed? We are anxious that you should give these matters your immediate consideration and, if you deem it at all necessary, we might send Mr. A. J. Doucet down to assist you in this task. Mr. Doucet, however, has been absent from the office for several weeks and we are not anxious to send him to Shubenacadie unless his presence there is absolutely necessary.

R. A. Hoey,
Acting Director.
It was with regret I learned of the necessity to postpone for another year the construction of the Agency administrative buildings. However I do not think that this decision will retard to any extent the movement of families to this reserve. The education of the children is not a matter of paramount interest to many Indian families and, if and when, the present school is unable to accommodate new-comers the construction of it lends itself to easy extension. We have sufficient lumber and labor and an enlargement under the direction of Mr. Robb is not a very difficult proposition. There are only twenty-three pupils attending this school and I feel that the present teacher is able to instruct almost twice that number without undue work. I feel that in this regard you need have no concern.

The present office site is satisfactory. During the summer when the roads are passable it is no trouble to be in the vicinity of the new houses whenever necessary. In the winter or while the mills are in operation it is, perhaps, better located than one on the old reserve would be.

When notice that these buildings were not going ahead, arrived, we were doing the preliminaries before moving the houses which interfere with the proposed constructions. This has now been abandoned in favour of the more important task, that of building Indian houses.

As much as we would enjoy having Mr. Doucet visit with us I feel, since he is so urgently needed elsewhere, and no serious difficulties apparent, that his presence here, though enjoyable and welcome, is not urgently required. The only change contemplated is an easy addition to the present day school.

Dr. McGill

Re: New Indian Day School at Shubenacadie, N.S.

Your memorandum of March 1st advised that for the fiscal year 1944-45 an amount of $75,000 was included for new Indian day schools to be erected at Shubenacadie and Eskasoni in 1944. Your memorandum of April 14th refers only to the new school at Shubenacadie and this, coupled with Mr. Buck's verbal advice of discussions with your officers, gives us the understanding that the day school at Shubenacadie is the only building in Nova Scotia Reserves that under present plans you wish us to undertake during 1944-45. Consequently, unless advised to the contrary, we are making our plans on this basis and with the objective of having the building ready for occupation on September 1st next.

Re-writing of certain of the forms and specifications, necessary because specifications prepared last year covered buildings at both Shubenacadie and Eskasoni, is under way and it is the intention to call for tenders at the earliest possible date. The plans already prepared and approved for the Shubenacadie day school will be used. It is also proposed to extend the scope of the newspaper advertisements in the hope that the decrease in building operations in the Maritimes on account of the war, will result in more favourable tenders being received.

The question of whether this school could be erected by day labour has been carefully considered but all the factors indicate that erection by contract is preferable at this time. Our Engineering and Construction Service has not its former day labour organization and it would be difficult to obtain a construction foreman of known competence, together with carpenters, for this one comparatively small project. Materials and labour priorities would also present difficulties.

There would also be difficulty in the transportation of supplies and the undertaking of excavation work and concrete work.

On the other hand building contractors have always the nucleus of a permanent organization and know of experienced carpenters who look to them for employment from time to time. They have the necessary contacts with firms handling building materials and with sub-contractors who can do excavation and concrete work, if necessary.

In your memorandum of April 21st you refer to the information that you just received from Mr. W.S. Arnell, Inspector of Indian Agencies, regarding Mr. Fred Robson, a local building contractor on small projects, who would be willing to work on a seasonal basis for some $6.00 per day, and has contact with three or four carpenters whom he employs at various times. It is the view that Mr. Robson and his carpenters could obtain suitable employment with the contractor who might be awarded the work. Mr. Arnell could be advised to let Mr. Robson know when the construction of the day school is advertised, so that he could get in touch with contractors who are interested.

It is our understanding that in so far as the day school at Shubenacadie is concerned, provision for a water supply at present will be limited to the installation of outside tanks for the wash basins in the basement and which can be connected up later on with any water supply system that is developed. In the meantime water for drinking and washing purposes will be brought to the school from near-by springs in buckets or barrels.
As it is our definite understanding that flush toilets are not required for the day school building, these have not been provided for and the design of the building in plan or elevation does not afford space for them. If later on toilets with running water were decided upon, it would be necessary to build an addition at ground floor level.

The question of a water supply for the Shubenacadie administrative unit has been the cause of delay and has required a good deal of study and investigation by our engineering officers. Last summer a well drilled near the proposed site proved unsatisfactory and on the advice of the Water Supply and Borings Section of the Mines and Geology Branch, further drilling was discontinued.

Early this month a test was made on an Indian well in the vicinity of the existing school with the view that if there was ample water there, the proposed residential group of buildings might be moved to the vicinity. However a test of this well undertaken by your Indian Agent, Mr. Rice, showed that the capacity of the well was far below that required.

Spring Creek is consequently the only satisfactory source of water supply and it was examined last fall by Mr. N.A. Sparks of our Engineering and Construction Service. A suitable intake for a pipe line is available about three-quarters of a mile from the proposed site of the buildings and there is ample water available. However as the intake is some 40 feet lower than the building site, pumping from the intake through a pipe line would be necessary. In order to protect the source of the spring it is considered that your Branch should secure an adjacent land on both sides of the road which might involve the purchase of about 150 acres. Mr. Rice expressed the view to Mr. Sparks that this land could be obtained at a very low price. In view of the fact that the village of Shubenacadie has made some investigations in connection with Spring Creek as a source of water supply, it is suggested that this land be obtained in the near future.

The design of a water supply system based on Spring Creek requires an estimate of what the eventual building development will be at the Shubenacadie centre so that the essentials of the original installation will be adequate to meet future requirements. Plans have already been prepared of four buildings, namely - day school, teachers' residence, principal's residence, agency office and warehouse. A water supply will be required for all of these.

Experience has shown that other buildings may eventually be required, among these being -

Agent's residence
Doctor's residence
Nursing Station
R.C.M. Police quarters

As even the buildings for which plans have been prepared will represent a considerable investment, it is the opinion that besides a domestic water supply, a reasonable degree of fire protection should also be provided for. Generally then the installation of a water supply system will involve the following:

An electric pole line to provide power for operating the pump motor and to give electric light and power to the various buildings.

4800 feet of water pipe and its installation.

Erection of pump-house and installation of suction pipe, etc.
The purchase and installation of a suitable pump and fittings.

The purchase and erection of a 5000 gallon water tank on a tower 60 feet high and which would be kept full by automatic operation of the pump. This would give a gravity supply of water for ordinary domestic needs.

Arrangement of valves so that if required in case of fire and after the tank is empty, water could be pumped directly through fire hose.

The provision of sewage disposal facilities in the nature of septic tanks.

Resume of Activities at Shubenacadie Agency During the Months of July and August, 1944.

When the tenders for the new school had to be in Ottawa by the 31st of May I had some hopes that the new school would be ready for occupation shortly after the beginning of the school term. Major D.A. McDonald, of the construction company of the same name, first arrived here on July 4th. About two weeks later his foreman and one helper arrived on the scene. They were followed on the 24th by a bull-doser and then a cement mixer. They picked up some help, both Indian and white, were held up some by erratic shipments of lumber, basement window frames, etc., and at the present have the basement excavated and the foundation walls completed. They are preparing now to install the necessary plumbing and pour the concrete for the floor. In exchange for the hundred thirty six dollars we owe them for the use of their bull-doser on our road, I have arranged to haul them one hundred yards of gravel from our pit. It will work out that we will have a little profit which we can use to good advantage hauling gravel on our road.

Engineer N.A. Sparks of the Engineering and Construction Service arrived here to supervise this building on July 17th and is still with us. The Chief Engineer, Mr. T.S. Mills, arrived here on the 16th inspecting the school site and talked over the advisability of drilling another well. At the present rate of progress it is problematical whether the school will be in readiness before the new year.

When I was advised that we were authorized to drill another well I contacted O.V. Kennedy, Esq., of Bridgetown N.S., asking him to come up at his earliest opportunity and go over with me the so-called administration centre and select a suitable site. He arrived here on the 4th of August and we agreed upon what we thought would be a likely spot. He promised to send his very best machine and operators and the outfit arrived here on the 15th. The began work the next day and have been working almost continuously ever since. At a depth of 132 ft. they found water which rose to a height of 30 ft. in the pipe. They were not in rock and although the water stayed with them to a degree it was not in the desired quantity. They drilled day after day and since about 75 ft. it was always in sand or fine gravel. They drove case pipe almost foot for foot with the drill and at the end of August they had reached a depth of 175 ft. still in the same sand and gravel formation.

H.C. Riggs, Indian Agent.

As you are aware delays which occurred after the award of a contract to D.A. Macdonald, General Contractor of Moncton, New Brunswick, for erection of the above, prevented the start of operations until late in July last.

Further difficulties of which you have been advised regarding trouble experienced by the contractor in obtaining carpenters and other skilled labour, has delayed the completion of the contract within the time limit set out in the contract agreement namely, August 31st, 1944.

This Service has endeavoured to obtain from Macdonald through Mr. Sparks an approximation of the date by which the building would be ready for acceptance, and under date of the 10th instant, Mr. Sparks has advised that with the exception of outside painting the contractor considers all work should be completed by February 1st, 1945.

It is our opinion however, in view of progress to date and factors contributing thereto, that such a date has very little significance.

We recommend therefore that authority be obtained from the Department to extend the date for completion to March 31st, 1945. Under the most favourable circumstances it will likely be necessary to provide an amount of approximately $500.00 in 1945-46 estimates to cover painting work which will not be completed until next spring.

The Deputy Minister

Attached herewith is a copy of a memorandum received from Mr. Mills, Chief Engineer, in regard to the date of completion by contract of the Indian Day School at Shubenacadie. Delay in the construction of this building has been due to labour shortage. The contractor, Major Macdonald, has interviewed Selective Service officers at Halifax on many occasions but gets no assistance as that Service apparently takes the position that this project is non-essential and has no priority in the labour market. Another disadvantage in securing men is that the wage rates authorized by the Department of Labour are not attractive when compared with wages paid for similar work in Halifax. The work is also located too far away from any large centre to obtain the benefit of the services of soldiers or sailors when on leave.

You will recall that on November 17th a letter was sent to the Associate Director of National Selective Service (Mobilization) forwarding a formal application from the contractor for ten enlisted men. This request was refused.

Under the circumstances the recommendation of Mr. Mills that the date of completion for the contract be forwarded to March 31st, 1945, is concurred in.

A copy of this memorandum and Mr. Mills' memorandum is being forwarded to the Acting Director of the Indian Affairs Branch for his information.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR, SURVEYS AND ENGINEERING BRANCH

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School

With reference to the Principal's residence and teacher's residence to be erected this summer on the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve, I would appreciate it if you would provide for hot-water heating in both of these buildings instead of hot-air heating.

Director.
With regard to the new School, which is finally completed, excepting installation of registers for the floors and these have not arrived from the manufacturers as yet. This has been a long drawn out process—about fifteen months constructing the building. I feel however that MacDonald, the Contractor, has done a real good job and that nothing has been slighted in any way. We certainly have a nice building and it is a great credit to the Reserve. Throughout the job, most of the work was done by two men and Indians from the Reserve supplied the remainder of the labour. This building will require a lot of attention both inside and outside and I intend to burn wood in the furnace for this year, as there is plenty on hand with only two classrooms to be heated. I have recommended Joseph Ross, the only competent Indian I have, for the job. He lives near the school and I have recommended his salary at the rate of $50.00 per month.

Although this might seem rather high, yet the building will require someone to look after it day and night and considering circumstances, I do not think this rate too unreasonable. I am waiting Departmental instructions on this matter. As I had to hire two teachers at the beginning of the school term, expecting that the new building would be ready, it has been necessary to have two sessions each day in the old school, one in the morning for the higher grades and another in the afternoon for the lower grades. Because there was not room in the old school, this has been necessary. Immediately the seats, desks and chairs arrive, I intend to open two rooms of the new school as this will be sufficient for this year and will be easier to heat. Mr. Ross of the Engineering Service was here for two weeks, surveying out the water line from the spring back to the Reserve. He found abundance of water and an analysis showed it to be in first class condition. He also inspected the new School and found it to his entire satisfaction. While construction of the building since last Christmas, has taken up quite a lot of my time, due to the fact that there was no Engineer here, Mr. Ross' favourable comments made me feel that time I had spent on it had been well worthwhile.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.
We finally managed to move into our new School the first of November. Two classrooms only are in use and these have been kept warm quite easily by burning wood. Because the remainder of the School has been closed off, it has been possible to heat the two rooms fairly easily. However I feel sure that when the time arrives and we have four teachers, we will have to use coal for a few months in place of wood. I had some gravel spread around on the School grounds, but there is still considerable work to be done in order to make the playgrounds attractive. In the Spring I will endeavour to get some crushed rock which will make it much drier and should show a much greater improvement. The children are all watched carefully regarding their school attendance and in case of absentees, the Constable is notified and a full explanation is required from the parents. We had Mr. Ross from the Survey and Engineering Branch, checking on the new School and surveying out the proposed waterline.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Reserve Water Supply

I informed you in a memorandum, dated March 6th, that the sum of $35,000.00 was provided in this year's est rates (Indian Education Vote) for the above work, this being the estimate of the cost of providing water for the agency buildings, etc., etc., on the Shubenacadie Reserve. It is the intention this year to provide the money required to build a 14,000 gallon concrete reservoir required for the storage of water for the Indians. Memorandum

The Chief Treasury Officer,

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Reserve Water Supply

The water supply system to serve the agency buildings, school, etc., is estimated to cost $35,000.00, and this sum has been provided in the Indian Education Vote.

In addition, it has been decided to provide water for the Indians and this year we intend to proceed with a portion of the work only. The plan is to build a two celled buried concrete reservoir from one portion of which the agency buildings, school, etc., will be supplied with water and from the other portion the Indians will secure their water. Will you kindly arrange to transfer to the Surveys and Engineering Branch a sum of $10,000.00 from the sum of $35,000.00 provided in the Indian Education vote. Will you also transfer from the Welfare Vote a sum of $4,500.00 so that when the concrete tank is being built there will be funds on hand from which to pay the share of the cost of the tank chargeable to the Welfare Vote as this is a service for the Indians.

I may say that the Surveys and Engineering Branch have ordered some materials and are waiting for the transfer of funds to pay accounts.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Indian Day School,
Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

Your notation dated the 23rd ultimo, on a memorandum from Mr. Hoey of June 6th last, requests a report on the condition of the interior finish at the above.

In this connection we may comment as follows:

It will be recalled that this school was built at a time in 1945, when subsequent delays in obtaining materials resulted in the admittance of considerable moisture to the interior of the building and as a consequence the gypsum board finish was applied in a puddled state when the building was put into use and the heating system began operation, the drying out process began and shrinkage of materials with subsequent movement caused the breaking up and expulsion of the joint filler between gypsum board sheets.

During his present assignment at Shubenacadie, our Mr. Ross noticed this condition and reported it to this office. He stated that when the joints were filled, the standard practice of applying tape over the joints before painting was not observed. It should be stated that this phase and construction was carried out while our supervising officer was unavoidably recalled to Ottawa, at which time Indian Agent Rice was endeavouring to observe and report on progress. It is evident that Mr. Rice was unable to interpret our specification.

There is no doubt that the existing situation is unpleasant and it was as the suggestion to this Service through Mr. Ross, that a tender for refilling and taping the joints was to have been obtained.

It was not our opinion however, that complete interior re-painting would need to be carried out, or hardwood floors re-varnished, although these items have been included in the tender submitted.

When Mr. Ross was in Ottawa recently, he stated that the exterior paintwork had not stood up, and that interior paintwork appeared to be an unsatisfactory job.

When it is considered that the Contractor D.A. McDonald submitted a tender for $17,000 for this school which was accepted and that a similar school recently completed at Eskasoni cost in the neighbourhood of $85,000, it is obvious that through his poor estimating McDonald lost money and it now appears that the paintwork is one item on which he skimped.

The tender for refilling and taping the joints and for re-executing a large portion of the school paintwork obtained by the Indian Agent and forwarded here by

Reference is made to your memorandum of June 6th last to which was attached a copy of a tender from Mr. R. H. Russell for re-painting the recently constructed Indian day school at Shubenacadie and regarding which you asked for our comments.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

Piano for Shubenacadie Indian Day School -

We have received this year many requests for pianos for our Indian day schools. These requests have been rejected and our policy has been to provide only pianos for day schools of at least three rooms and more in size. This policy has been adopted because of the change over in teachers which occurs in our Indian day schools. This has resulted in our providing a piano for a school one year, to find that next year the teacher with musical ability had moved on elsewhere leaving no one capable of using the piano for musical instruction.

To date the only piano authorized for purchase was at the four-room Eskasoni Day School. During my recent inspection trip to the Maritimes I advised Mr. Indian Agent Rice to be on the lookout for a cheap recommissioned piano and to try and advise me if possible, so that the necessary purchase order could be obtained. However, this apparently was not possible, as most second hand piano dealers naturally want a decision immediately as to whether the instrument is to be sold or not.

Therefore I would recommend the issuance of a purchase order to cover this recommissioned piano. It has been examined by the music teacher at the school and found to be entirely satisfactory. There will be no difficulty in the Shubenacadie School with regard to a music teacher, as three of the four teachers on the staff are capable musicians.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: INDIAN DAY SCHOOL,

Before the commencement of the next Academic Year it is desirable that the following items be considered:

(1) The present heating system is inadequate for this School and it was understood that the present unit was to be replaced by a Hot Water System. We have received some materials from the Mount Pleasant Air Port which can be used in this conversion, however, the Furnace is not here and not nearly enough pipe to complete the job.

(2) You will no doubt remember that last Fall an accountable advance was received at this Office to effect the necessary repairs to the outside lavatories. Due to the fact that an early winter set in the amount of frost in the ground made it impossible to attempt this work. The money advanced was returned at the end of the fiscal year. It is felt that this work should be proceeded with at once so that a convenient sanitary set-up can be erected.

It is proposed to construct a large cribbed well under the present buildings which will be removed to a new site in order that a better play ground can be provided. From this well irrigation pipe will lead to a suitable disposal bed. The front of the present buildings when moved to their new Con. Sheet # 2.
location will be suitably camouflaged with lattic work to create good display.

(3) It is absolutely necessary that a suitable play ground be completed this year. The lavatories are to be moved from their present site to allow for this work, but although some ground will be gained much work will have to be done behind the School and on the North side. Most of this work can be done with the Agency Tractor and Truck, but some other expenditure for equipment Etc., will be necessary to bring the play ground up to the standard desired.

May these requests receive favourable consideration and could we be advised at your earliest convenience your decision and recommendations in respect to these matters.

Reference to your letter of August 13th last respecting the heating and electric wiring of the Indian Day-School on the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve.

There seems to be some understanding as to the amount of surplus plumbing equipment which is available at this Agency for the job in question. As you are possibly aware we did receive certain amount of equipment by box-car during the past winter from Mount Pleasant Airport, P.E.I.

Further we dispatched our truck to Lennox Island on August 9th last to take up the balance of the surplus equipment there. Although Mr. Daley was not on hand to supervise the loading it is understood that we obtained all the surplus equipment that was available.

We possibly have enough radiators on hand at the present time to complete the job, however, a considerable amount of pipes will have to be purchased. We have written Mr. Daley sometime ago requesting information as to whether we can expect to receive anything further in the line of plumbing equipment from his Agency. To date we have not received a reply and it is felt that in view of the short time that is left before the opening of school, this matter should be drawn to your attention so that we can obtain further instructions from you as to what action is to be taken.
Should we hear from Mr. Daley within the next day or two the contents of his letter will be wired to you so that you will be in a better position to advise us in this problem.

There is a plumber at present employed on the Reserve who would be available to commence the job as soon as the plans arrive at this office and your further instructions are received.

Memorandum:

Education Division,
Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

Re: Installation of hot-water system in
the Indian Day School -
Shubenacadie, N.S.

We are returning herewith Voucher No. 82 which
you forwarded to this office, with a request that our Mr.
J. E. Hall investigate the prices shown in the invoices of
J. D. Barrett of Truro, N.S.

While in Shubenacadie, Mr. Hall inspected the
installation of the hot-water system and found the system
working satisfactorily in the school rooms on the second
floor. However, one-third of the radiators on the ground
floor are not working satisfactorily, and the contractor,
Barrett, states that this is due to the fact that certain
changes were requested in the installation by Mr. Hargreaves
of the Engineering Services, which changes also increased
the cost of installation considerably. It appears that the
contractor had prepared to install radiators at or near the
ceiling of the ground floor, and Mr. Hargreaves insisted on
having the radiators placed on the floor, which necessitated
considerable additional work.

At the same time, it was pointed out that it was
necessary to transport labour from Truro to Shubenacadie,
which required 3/4 of an hour each way, as well as transpor-
tation charges. This, of course, also increased the cost of
installation. Otherwise, the prices shown on the Barrett
invoices appear to be fair and reasonable.

Cont'd......
It is believed that Mr. Rice, the Superintendent at Shubenacadie, is to have the contractor, Barrett, investigate the actual reasons for the unsatisfactory heating by one-third of the radiators on the first floor, and just what action will be taken I cannot predict. However, it is recommended that your Branch should contact Superintendent Rice and give him your instructions, and request any further information which you may require in this connection.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Shubenacadie Four-Room Indian Day School,
Shubenacadie Indian Agency, Province of Nova Scotia.

Last August it was decided to change the heating unit from hot air to hot water at the above mentioned school. At the time the work commenced, there were on hand at Shubenacadie radiators, valves, pipes, etc., which had been salvaged from the Mt. Pleasant Airport Hospital which had been previously turned over to the Indian Affairs Branch. It was also expected that our caretaker at Shubenacadie could do a considerable amount of the work.

However, as the season was advancing and the work was proceeding very slowly, Indian Superintendent Rice made arrangements with Mr. J.D. Barrett, Truro, Nova Scotia, to take over the work in order to have it completed before the cold weather set in. It was also found when the work was actually started that a considerable amount of additional material was required. This was also supplied by Mr. Barrett. When the work was completed, the Indian Superintendent submitted three Vouchers issued in favour of Mr. Barrett, which were as follows:

(1) Materials.......................... $1,138.16
(2) Labour............................ 1,150.25
(3) Transportation of labourers from Truro to Shubenacadie... 173.60

$2,462.01

CANADA
The amounts mentioned above were much higher than the Departmental officials expected, and we had the newly installed system inspected. We learned that the system which had been in use during most of the past winter, had proved satisfactory. It was also ascertained that the cost was increased due to the fact that certain changes were requested in the installation by an officer of the engineering services of the Lands & Development Services Branch. It appears that the contractor had been prepared to install the radiators at or near the ceiling on the ground floor, but the engineer from the Lands & Development Services Branch insisted on having the radiators placed on the floor, which necessitated considerable additional work.

We also ascertained that it was necessary, in order to complete the work, to transport labourers from Truro to Shubenacadie, which required three-quarters of an hour each way as well as transportation charges. This, of course, also increased the cost of installation.

The prices shown on the Invoices received from Mr. Barrett appear to be fair and reasonable. We would, therefore, appreciate it if you would approve payment of the accounts which have been submitted by Mr. Barrett, in an amount of $2,462.01. He is urging immediate payment as the work has been completed for some time, but submission of the matter to you has been delayed until our officials had made a thorough investigation and decided that the expenditure was reasonable for the amount of work performed.

Director.

Barrett, Truro, Nova Scotia, to take over the work in order to have it completed before the cold weather set in. It was also found when the work was actually started that a considerable amount of additional material was required. This was also supplied by Mr. Barrett. When the work was completed, the Indian Superintendent submitted three Vouchers issued in favour of Mr. Barrett, which were as follows:

(1) Materials ........................................ $1,138.16
(2) Labour ........................................... 1,150.25
(3) Transportation of labourers from Truro to Shubenacadie ........................................ 173.60

$2,462.01
The amounts mentioned above were much higher than the Departmental officials expected, and we had the newly installed system inspected. We learned that the system which had been in use during most of the past winter had proved satisfactory. It was also ascertained that the cost was increased due to the fact that certain changes were requested in the installation by an officer of the engineering services of the Lands & Development Services Branch. It appears that the contractor had been prepared to install the radiators at or near the ceiling on the ground floor, but the engineer from the Lands & Development Services Branch insisted on having the radiators placed on the floor, which necessitated considerable additional work.

We also ascertained that it was necessary, in order to complete the work, to transport labourers from Truro to Shubenacadie, which required three-quarters of an hour each way as well as transportation charges. This, of course, also increased the cost of installation.

The prices shown on the Invoices received from Mr. Barrett appear to be fair and reasonable. We would, therefore, appreciate it if you would approve payment of the accounts which have been submitted by Mr. Barrett, in an amount of $2,462.01. He is urging immediate payment as the work has been completed for some time, but submission of the matter to you has been delayed until our officials had made a thorough investigation and decided that the expenditure was reasonable for the amount of work performed.

MEMORANDUM:

DEPUTY MINISTER.

Re: Change-over of heating system, Shubenacadie four-room Indian day school, from hot air to hot water.

You returned departmental memorandum of June 11th with a notation to the effect that you wished to know who authorized this change and also asked if it was approved by the Minister or Deputy Minister. Since the memorandum was returned, I have consulted the Superintendent of Education and also Mr. Morris, who was the Acting Regional Supervisor for the Maritime Provinces at the time this change-over was made. Mr. Morris has prepared a memorandum under date of July 4th, which you will find on file immediately hereunder.

Apparently the question of getting authority was not thought of at the time, as it was felt that when the purchase order was issued for the purchase of a hot water boiler this approved the principle of the change-over. You will note from Mr. Morris' memorandum that the hot air system was entirely inadequate to heat the school, and particularly the two basement rooms, in the proper manner. Although the change-over cost a considerable amount of money, the total cost of this school is still only a little more than half the cost of a similar building at Eskasoni.

Mr. Barrett, who did the heating and plumbing work, has forwarded a further telegram to the Branch indicating that the non-payment of his account is jeopardising his credit with his suppliers. While we realize that authority should have been obtained from Head Office prior to authority having been given for the work, I would recommend that approval be now given, in order that we may pay Mr. Barrett's account. As set out in memorandum of June 11th, it is felt that the expenditure was reasonable for the work performed.

Acting Director.
Memorandum:

Acting Director.

Re: Installation of hot water heating unit - Shubenacadie 4-room day school.

The following is a brief explanation for the necessity of installing the hot water heating system in the above mentioned school.

The Shubenacadie 4-room school was constructed at a very low cost of approximately $20,000. A hot air heating unit was installed last to keep the cost down and 2nd electricity or water was not then available. The hot air heating unit proved that it was unable to heat the building adequately, in fact, it was never possible at any time to heat the two basement rooms, which were to be used for Manual Training and Domestic Science. I held several meetings with the Indians in the basement during the winter of 1948 and despite the fact that all the heating was turned on in the basement rooms, we had to conduct the meetings with overcoats and mufflers on.

When we were dismantling the hospital at Mount Pleasant Airport, at Prince Edward Island, we had a surplus quantity of radiators, pipes, elbows, tees, and valves. I pointed this fact out to the officers of the School Division and suggested that consideration should be given to installing a hot water heating system using these materials, which would substantially reduce the cost. At the time it was considered that Mr. George Johnston, the caretaker, would be able to do the work himself in his spare time without additional cost for the labour. He did not work out for the reason that when Mr. Johnston went through the blueprints he stated that he was unable to do the work properly. It was discovered during the summer of 1948 that the fire pot in the hot air furnace was burnt out and could not be used again during the winter of 1948-1949, as it would be a fire hazard. With Mr. Johnston unable to carry out the work, Superintendent Rice was instructed to investigate the possibilities of securing the services of a competent furnace man, or steam fitter who, with Mr. Johnston's assistance, would install the new heating unit. In the meantime, a hot water heating boiler was purchased, Order #3788.

Mr. Rice was unable to fulfil my request and as it was getting late in the season, it was imperative that something would have to be done. He sent in a quotation from Mr. J. D. Barrett, which we considered was too high. He was again asked to further investigate the possibility of securing a lower tender, but was unable to do so for the reason that it was very difficult for a contractor to make an estimate of the cost of a job of this kind keeping in mind that he had to use second-hand material and supply new material where required. After checking over the job, it was discovered that an extra quantity of radiators were required, Purchase Order #35739, dated November 10, 1948, was placed with Mr. Barrett for them.
Acting Director.

Ottawa, July 4, 1949.

This extra radiation was required to meet the specifications of the plans, as set out by the Engineering Division for the Eskasoni School, which are identical to the Shubenacadie 4-room school.

It is my personal opinion that this building could have been adequately heated with less radiation than was shown on the blueprints for the reason that Shubenacadie is located in an area where they have very mild winters, as the temperature very seldom goes below zero. However, the work has now been done and from reports is entirely satisfactory. The cost was considerably less because of the materials supplied from Mount Pleasant Airport.

I would, therefore, recommend that payment be made at the earliest possible date.

J. Z. Morris,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies for the Province of Ontario.

Dear Mr. Barrett:

In Mr. Abbott's absence from the city, I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 30th regarding a delay in receipt of payment of an account for the installation of a hot water heating system at the Indian School at Shubenacadie.

On making enquiries into this matter I am advised that the account is being held in the Education Service of the Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources.

You will realize that this is a matter coming under another department and I am taking the liberty of forwarding your letter to the Minister of Mines and Resources in an endeavour to have payment of your account expedited.

Yours very truly,

Doris L. Bentley
(Private Secretary)

C.C. Mr. J. G. Levy,
Private Secretary to the
Minister of Mines and Resources.
Hon. D.C. Abbott  
Minister of Finance,  
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Last Dec. we completed a Hot Water Heating System for the Dept. of Education at the Indain School, Shubenacadie, N.S. for the sum of $2462.00., as yet I have received no payment. Ottawa has been promising payment for months but without action. I have wired this department at Ottawa many times but they will not reply to these wires. I also asked our local man, G.T. Purdy to inquire but he also had little success. This account has been outstanding for six months and is jeopardizing my credit with my suppliers. I would appreciate any action you could arrange to assure prompt payment.

Yours respectfully,

J.D. Barrett,
Plumbing & Heating,
Truro, N.S.

Dear Sir,

There is no fit boarding place near and one could not lodge with the Indians, so I walk five miles in the morning to school and back again at night. Sir,

The enclosed letter explains itself. Miss Shortt describes the condition of teacher's residence at Shubenacadie very well. Besides being out of repair the building is too small for the purpose intended. Its dimensions are about 12 x 15 ft. and the wall is very low. If the roof were repaired, it would make a very good place for storing fuel for both school and teacher. There is no fuel shed at present and one is required. It would be regrettable if anything should happen to close the Indian Day School at Shubenacadie, because it is doing good work, under the capable management of Miss Shortt.

The exterior of the building was then nearing completion. I had an opportunity on Dec. 9th of observing what Mr. Shortt had accomplished up to that date under very unfavourable conditions, and would say that the work is being well done. If progress is not more rapid, the fact is entirely due to the difficulty of procuring suitable labour.

So far, the specifications have been adhered to, with one unavoidable exception: Siding was not obtainable, and with my approval shingles were substituted. As the result of experience, both personal and otherwise, I am convinced that shingles on the walls of a building are fully as durable as siding, and give better satisfaction.

Mr. Shortt suggests again the position of the flue in this case. He argues that it would be an advantage in heating the building to have it placed as near the centre of the house as possible, and built from a basement foundation. From what

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
what I have seen of flues resting on brackets, as shown in the plan, I would recommend making the alteration as suggested, which would entail an extra expenditure of about eight dollars.

I think it would be advisable to postpone the work of finishing the interior of the building till the Spring, because plastering cannot be properly done during the winter season in the country, where there is no sure way of keeping the putty from being chilled and frozen without going to considerable expense which would not be warranted in this case. But if the work cannot be discontinued for a couple of months, I would strongly advise substituting Beaver Board for the Plaster. I am aware that the former is being extensively used on the interior walls of new, up-to-date residences, as finishing, and it is claimed, with excellent satisfaction.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Ottawa, February 5, 1917.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter dated 20th ultimo in reference to teacher's residence at Shubenacadie, N.S.

The Department is pleased to learn that the work on the building is reported by you as being well done and that the specifications have been complied with excepting that shingles have been used on the exterior of the building instead of clapboards which could not be procured. The use of the shingles is commended under the circumstances and if these are suitably stained or painted will meet the requirements.

The Department will also approve of the extending of the chimney to foundation in the position shown, but cannot approve of the chimney being placed at the centre of the building as this will interfere with the arrangement planned and which cannot be improved on in this particular.

The work should be discontinued until more favourable weather, and before commencing, arrangements should be made for the necessary assistance as the pay of the foreman is altogether out of proportion to the cost of assistants.

The enclosed accounts for services rendered in connection with the erection of the teacher's residence at Shubenacadie Reserve were submitted recently by Mr. Shortt, Superintendent of construction.

In his report Mr. Shortt states that skilled labour is not available, and the statement may be accepted as severely correct. As a consequence, the work done on this house since the beginning of the year was performed by himself and an Indian, Tom Maloney, and there is no charge for Superintendent's duties during that time, which were not necessary under the circumstances, but were performed in a very practical manner nevertheless.

When I visited Shubenacadie Reserve on the 2nd inst., Mr. Shortt was at work lathing the interior walls and partitions of the building preparatory to plastering. He has decided to finish its construction himself with whatever assistance he can get from the Indians, which I think is about the only thing to be done under existing conditions.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have just received from Miss Mary A. Shortt, teacher of the Indian day school at Shubenacadie, N.S., your letter to her of the 11th inst. with reference to cleaning the teacher's residence recently erected there.

I instructed Miss Shortt to get the work done and, therefore, she has no responsibility in the matter. I did not think it any part of the janitor's duty to do this work, and am of the same opinion still. He is paid to furnish fuel to the school and to keep the school room in proper condition; and in view of the present price of hardwood fuel, he is certainly not too well paid for these services. There was no thought of a teacher's residence at Shubenacadie reserve when he was appointed.

Mrs. Tanner made a demand on me for $10.00, which I refused to consider until she would submit a proper statement of her claim, which she has finally done, and accordingly I forward herewith a Voucher in her favour for $2.00.

I need hardly mention that a new building finished in plaster wants cleaning very much before it can be occupied, and that the process involves a great deal of rubbing and scrubbing.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir—

The letter inclosed herewith explains itself. With regard to the cellar or basement of the teacher's residence at Shubenacadie Reserve, N.S., I beg to report that I examined last month and, therefore, have reason to think that Mrs. King's description of its condition is rather exaggerated. The outlet or drain from it seems to be choked, and any surface water getting into the cellar does not readily escape, which leaves the place damp and practically useless for the purpose it is intended—the storage of vegetables, etc., in cold weather.

I recommend that the drain be opened up and repaired at a cost not to exceed $20.00. I recommend also that an expenditure of $30.00 be authorized for the purchase of necessary materials to paper and paint the inside of the teacher's residence, where the work may be most required.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Dear Mr. Cameron:

Noel Julian has left us again. This time he took three others with him on Sunday evening just before supper time. By sunset we had overtaken two of the four, but Noel Julian and Peter Labobe of P.E.I. got into deep woods and we could not find them. About eight o'clock that night I went out over the ground with two officers of the R.C.M.P. We picked up their trail and kept after them until near midnight. Monday morning we found out that they had called at a house at 2 A.M. Monday. Before leaving there at 5 A.M. they at least had taken the old man's tobacco. They crossed Shubenacadie River on the ice, and were headed for Truro. On Monday morning the R.C.M.P. picked up their trail on the other side of the River, and we travelled miles after them. Whenever they found themselves near the main highway, they went back to the woods. I was getting over a cold, and all this travelling on Sunday and Monday, getting overheated and coming back and sitting in the car, has given me another, so I am in bed today.

There is no need to tell you what to do if they turn up in your Agency.

This is the fifth time for Noel Julian during the past two years, and I feel that Saint Patrick's Home is the only place for that imbecile.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Acting on instructions received from H.C.O., 1/6 Halifax Detachment, a patrol was made to Shubenacadie, via P.O. Code No. 1695, accompanied by Cst. MacKenzie. Patrol left Halifax at 9:30 a.m.; arrived at Shubenacadie at 10:30 a.m., 8:45.

On arrival at Indian School it was ascertained from L/Cpl. Cheeseman that the boys had left the school at 6 a.m. They had been seen near one of the farms at about 9:45 a.m., about six miles from the school in the direction of Shubenacadie. Patrol was made to this spot, and the track of the boys was picked up, and followed by P.A. Perky. The track was followed for about ½ of a mile when it was learned that the boys had been seen further up the road. We immediately went to this spot and the trail picked up again, and followed through the bush for a distance of approximately six miles in a circular direction.

The two boys parted, the trail of W. LeBellois being followed by the dog, eventually freeing the boy. Dog was returned to the place where the two boys split, and an attempt was made to pick up the trail of the other boy, but the dog was too tired to work.

L/Cpl. Cheeseman was contacted and the return trip was made to the school with the boy. At this time lunch was obtained, and a change of clothing for Cst. Roland.

About 4 p.m. a phone call was received from one of the farms along the road to the effect that the boy had been seen crossing the road near Ryans Creek. We returned immediately to this spot and the trail of the second boy was picked up by the dog, and followed for about ½ or ¾ of a mile through the bush, the boy being found after a short time.

This boy was returned to the authorities at the school and supper was obtained in Shubenacadie. Return to Halifax being made in P.O. Code No. 1695, driven by Cst. Tunney.

During the time the dog was searching in the woods, L/Cpl. Cheeseman and Cst. Tunney and Cst. MacKenzie patrolled the roads in the vicinity, keeping a lookout for the boys. During the search the writer was accompanied by L. Parker, one of the men from the school who was familiar with the country and the two boys.

In the opinion of the writer, the dog did a very efficient job under difficult circumstances, it being the first time he had done any work in the bush. The dog was bewildered at first, but soon settled down and followed the trail very well.

J.O. Roland

Roland in the woods and the number of the men, into darkness and members of this detachment took places along roads and good trails where watch could be kept in order that the two boys might not slip out of the woods which were some 2 to 3 miles in width and 5 or 6 miles in length.
