This date at about 6:45 A.M., report was received from sister superior of the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, that Leo TONKY and Wallace LEHMANN had departed from the school.

Immediate patrol was made in P/C CODE 1691 accompanied by Cst. Tunnah to the Stewiacke District. A party from the school went out the Haitland Road.

The services of Cst. Boland and P/D K 27 "Perky" were obtained from N.C.O. Halifax Detachment. LEHMANN was "tired" in the Admiral Rock District. LEHMANN stated that TONKY had left him. The whole party returned to Shubenacadie for refreshments no stop being made at noon for lunch.

A telephone message was received, whilst having lunch, that an Indian boy had been noticed near New Dublin (Shubenacadie side of Admiral Rock). Patrol was made towards New Dublin in P/C CODE 1691 accompanied by Csts. Tunnah and Boland with P/D K 27 "Perky". A party from the Residential School followed in their car.

Cst. Boland and P/D K 27 affected the capture of Leo TONKY within a short space of time in the Ryans Creek District.

TONKY was escorted back to the school in P/D CODE 1691.

Cst. Tunnah returned Cst. Boland and P/D K 27 to Halifax in the Late P.M., via P/C CODE 1691.

P/D K 27 "Perky" under the direction of Cst. Boland made an excellent showing and it is thought the performance will have a salutary affect on the boys at the school who might have notions of playing truants. The two boys that left were no amateurs in the woods and they employed many tricks to throw off pursuit. The boys would enter the thickest brush, under low branches, through swamps and over such humps as, and, as they approached. The boys at the school have been assured that a dog would be obtained to patrol them and the presence of a dog has been lauded. One may conscientiously state the results attained by Csts. Boland and P/D K 27 was most gratifying and over shadowed any exaggeration that might have been made to previous truants as to the results that would follow when a dog might be brought into service.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of June 8th, and the enclosed letter of Noel Sark, concerning the matter of vacation for his three children, Hannah, Laura May, and Harry.

We have already written all Agents who have children in the school about the matter of vacation, with the exception of Agent Darros of Bear River, Digby County. Last year he wrote direct to the Department about vacation for the five Louise children, and was refused. As we told Mr. Phelan when he was here, had Agent Darros written to us recommending vacation for the children, we would have sent them. This year we did not write to him.

Now to get back to the matter of our letter. We had a reply from Mr. Hudson saying that he did not want vacation for any of the children from his district. Further, the oldest Sark girl, Hannah, is sixteen, and we sent word in the same letter to Mr. Hudson that Hannah was eligible for discharge. In reply Mr. Hudson stated that he had not heard from the father for some time, and did not know where he was located. We informed him that the father was at Petitcodiac, and he advised us to send her there. So in any case, one will go.

We think the following information is true. The mother of these children died on the road a few years ago, and the story was that her death was caused by lack of nutrition. The father has married again, and judging
from his letter to you, and his letters to the children, he must be doing better. We might say that all three children when they came here were poorly nourished, and indicated in many ways that they had very little care.

The way we feel about vacation is that since the Agent in the different localities send the children here, they, the Agents, know the home conditions, and we leave it to them to say whether or not any child will go home for vacation. As far as we are concerned, we would be glad to see them all go home for vacation.

So we are sending Mr. Hudson a copy of this letter, and enclosing the letter of Mr. Sark. If Mr. Hudson wishes Laura May and Harry to go home for vacation, we will send them along with the rest of the children at the end of the month, provided that Mr. Sark lives up to his end of the bargain, and sends us the railway fare for the three, or even for the two younger ones, because the oldest Hannah will be sent in any case.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Dear Father Mackey:

I have the copy of a letter you sent the Department re the Sark Children. With regard to sending Laura May and Harry, home for vacation, I cannot yet see that it would be to their advantage, or pleasure either, that they should go.

As for any improvement in this Noel Sark, none can be expected, as I do not believe he will take any care of those children if they do go to him. What he is trying for, is to have the children go home, and then apply to the Department for relief, and out of what he would probably get, he would live himself and let the children go hungry as he did when his first wife was alive.

I would like to see the children have a vacation, but when I know it would mean to them nothing but hardship I cannot agree to give them any, that is if it is left to me to decide. So I would let Hannah go to her father but keep the younger ones.

Yours respectfully

Signed Chas. Hudson

The Secretary:

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit report of N.B. Southwestern Indian Agency for month of July

WOODSTOCK RESERVE

Madeline Sacobie, who came to me from the Shubenacadie school has been removed from her sister's home in the New Reserve, Devon, N.B. to Woodstock. Just another case of a girl being discharged from our school where she has had the security of that school over a period of years and then sent to me; one by one I have watched them revert to type even though we move heaven and earth to save them. I do not wish to be presumptuous, but I would make a suggestion, i.e. a month or so before a girl is discharged from the Shubenacadie Home that belongs to me, I be notified and not put off until I receive a wire that she will be in St John a certain day. I have placed in the last four years some thirty girls in white homes as domestics. Some of them have let me down and been failures, but I am more than satisfied with the average. With your permission I would ask authority to take this question, which to me is a problem, up with the Reverend J.P. Mackey.

R. Lee McCutcheon,
Indian Agent.
Dpts. Indian Affairs

Dear Sir,

On the morning of August 31, at 4:00 A.M., accompanied by a matron, I proceeded to St. John with Myrtle Sacobie, Indian child of the Oromocto Reserve age 8 years to put her on the train for Shubenacadie, N. S.

On the way down the child became very ill. Was nauseated and vomited several times with the result that I reached the station in St. John five minutes too late to connect with the train. Dear Sir,

This Mrs. Smith, so far, is a pretty sensible person. I went into the case at length, and find she is concerned about the condition of her family and household owing to their limited means. September 17, 1939.

Mr. Neil MacDougall,
Indian Agent,
Summerside, P.E.I.

Dear Mr. MacDougall:

We have a letter of September 8th, 1929, saying that Mary Ann Lewis is to go to her home. You are supposed to have a copy of this letter from Ottawa.

You will note in the letter that they leave the arrangements to us here. We would wish it otherwise. However, we propose the following, and hope it will meet with your approval.

If you would arrange with the mother and pay her expenses to come to Cape Tormentine, we would take the girl from here to the boat by car, and the mother could look after her from there on. We would pay Mary Ann's fare, and if you would let us know the expenses for the mother, we would send you a cheque for that amount. The greatest difficulty would be getting the girl aboard and off the train. Between here and the boat it would mean six changes, so if we took her by car to the boat, it would be much more convenient and would save the mother the trip by train from the boat down here and back. We would have to have a few days notice so that there would be no hitch in meeting the mother. Will you please let us know what you think about it.

We are enclosing admission form for the Bernard children. They are complete except for your signature. We are sending on the forms to Ottawa for Edward Justin Labobe and Raymond Lewis.

Dear Sir:

Shortly after Mrs. Michael Denny's death on August 30th, I investigated as to how Mr. Denny would take care of his children. He made the statement at the time that Mr. & Mrs. Mathew Sapier were moving in with him and would look after the children. They did but did not stay there very long with the result that his two boys, Francis, age 12 and Gordon John are very neglected.

Francis goes to school occasionally; last week it was reported to me that he was intoxicated. Gordon John goes to school fairly regularly but the both children have no one to prepare their meals as the father is away most of the time. Mr. Denny does not want to have his children sent to Shubenacadie school, believing wrongly of course, that children there are not well cared for, especially since the triple escape of an older son, Gregory, who is now at St. Patrick's school, Halifax.

In view of the above facts, I strongly recommend that these two children be sent to Shubenacadie school, and ask the Department how to proceed to have the children sent there. I understand that forms (which I have on hand) are to be filled, but I know that Mr. Denny will not sign his name to them.

Your obedient servant,

Indian agent

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 5th instant regarding Schurman Peters.

If this boy's mother is dead and there is no one to care for him the Department doubts the advisability of discharging him from the Shubenacadie Residential School simply for the purpose of obtaining an extra $12.00 a month separation allowance. Even if this amount were paid it would not go to the father but would go to the boy or whoever was looking after him. If he were placed with an Indian it is doubtful if he would receive as good attention as he is receiving in the Shubenacadie School.

You should take up with the military authorities the question of whether or not they will pay the separation allowance in the event of the boy remaining in the Shubenacadie School. Such procedure was followed during the last war and the money so obtained was paid to the Department and funded to the credit of the recipient and used for assistance when discharge was finally granted from the residential school.

Ottawa, May 4, 1943.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 30th ultimo and also a communication received by you from Dr. J. E. Robertson. It is noted that both these communications relate to the children of Henry Charles, Seymout, N. S.

I am anxious that there should be no misunderstanding in your mind with respect to sending telegrams to this Department. The officials of this Bureau are acting under explicit orders from the office of the Minister when, in dealing with Indian agents, they insist that only in very urgent and exceptional cases should telegrams be sent to this Department and that on such occasions the messages should be very brief.

It is noted that you received a letter relating to the welfare of these children on March 18 from Dr. Robertson and it is also noted that you did not send forward the telegram until April 5th.

If you consult my letter to you dated April 5th, 1943, you will note I stated in that communication that it was your responsibility to discuss this matter very thoroughly with the Indian himself and to make the best possible arrangements you could make, in view of all the circumstances. I have nothing to add to these instructions. You should make provision for the care of these children in an Indian home, if possible. Toward the middle of August you should submit an application forms for the three children ranging in age from 8 to 10 for admission to the Shubenacadie residential school. I regret that it is not possible to enroll these children at the residential school until the end of the present academic year. The younger children, who are not of school age, can not be admitted to the Shubenacadie school.

If Charles succeeds in securing employment and refuses to contribute to the support of his children, you, as Indian agent, should take the ordinary court action usually taken in such cases. The Department is not asking you to do the impossible, but in times such as these, even Indian parents must assume some responsibility for the support of their children. In the meantime, any arrangement you make for the support of these children in a home, where they may be in satisfactory conditions, will be acceptable to the Department. If Weldon Charles and Moses Charles, both of whom are referred to by Dr. Robertson in his communication, need medical care, you should submit a specific recommendation on both cases to the Superintendent of Medical Services of this Branch.

Yours truly,

H. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Sir:

I hereto acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 24th instant File 51-0-10 with enclosure from the Chief and Councillor of the Bel Ground Reserve requesting that two of their children be sent home from Shubenacadie for the summer vacation. In reply I have to state that I am pleased to know that your view of this request is the same as my own. I have already told those people that funds were scarce and could not be spared for such purposes, and that no children whose homes were as far from the school as New Brunswick, could have vacations.

With regard to those two children of the Bel Ground Reserve I could not say that they have suitable homes to go to, and undoubtedly we would also have trouble in getting them to go back.

I am returning the Indians letter and would not that it would be a good plan to have any of my agency children go home from Shubenacadie for vacation.

I have the honour to be

Sir

your obedient servant

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 26th instant the admission of Moses and Albert Bernard to the Shubenacadie Residential School is approved.

From the first paragraph of your letter I presume that you were not consulted before these children were placed in the Shubenacadie School. Is it your desire that the Principal be informed not to accept any children from Prince Edward Island unless he has first heard from you?

I feel that there must be some definite decision made regarding when children are to be admitted from Prince Edward Island to Shubenacadie. It is rather unsatisfactory to have them enter the school without any approval having been granted. At the same time the Principal of the Shubenacadie School cannot be blamed as the Indians bring the children and presumably tell him that you have approved. Please let me know your wishes in the matter in order that we can avoid such difficulties in the future.

As I informed you in my letter of the 24th instant no other children should be sent to the Shubenacadie School this year as there is no accommodation for additional pupils.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of November 21st, with the enclosed copy of the letter which you received from Agent Spinney dated November 14th.

When Agent Spinney wrote us about these children, the Agents of Parrsboro, Pictou, and Richibucto, had already received approval from the Department for children of these Agencies to enter the school. Although at the time, we had in the school the number of children for which grant is allowed, we advised these Agents to send on the children. When Mr. Spinney wrote we thought it possible that some of these children from Parrsboro, Pictou, and Richibucto, may not come, so we wrote to Mr. Spinney to make application to the Department, and if approved, then it might be possible for us to accept some or all of them. However, it so happened that all the children from Parrsboro, Pictou, Antigonish, and Richibucto arrived. So at the present time we have seventy eight girls, and eighty one boys, a total of a hundred and fifty nine, well above the number for which "grant" is allowed.

We have completed blood tests, vaccinations, and Schick test, and toxoid treatment is well under way. The question of finance being what it is, we do not feel that at the present time we should be obliged to care for more children than we now have. However, we shall remember for next September that the children from Mr. Spinney's Agency will be the first to be admitted.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sirs—

Will you kindly speed up your reply to Corporal Harold Johnson Agent in regard to sending my daughter to the College at Shubenacadie.

I asked Mr. Johnson to write for me in November, thinking that I might have her in school at the beginning of the new year, but Mr. Johnson says he has had no reply yet.

Will you kindly instruct Corporal Johnson how to act toward the matter.

She was going to the convent school at Eastern Passage but since they have been building the new air-port, they have the roads torn up so badly that they are impassable. It is a long lonely 4 miles, for a girl.
to travel all alone, anyhow.

My daughters and I went up to see the College on Nov. 12th, and the sisters showed us all through, and I thought it was a wonderful place, everything they teach here is useful knowledge.

I am 55 years old myself, but I would like to have a few years there, because one is never too old to learn something new, especially the beautiful pottery they do there. So I hope to get my daughters there as soon as I possibly can, in a couple more years, she will be old enough to register, and perhaps get in an ammunition factory somewhere in Canada. I would like to have a job in an ammunition factory too. It would be the greatest thrill to me if I knew that my hands helped to polish the bomb or shell that would smash Hitler. But they don't give us Indians a chance to do our bit. We feel patriotic, too remember.
Please reply to me in person or through our good Agent Corporal Harold Johnston.

I will remain yours

Very Truly,

August 7th, 1941.

Dear Sir:

Barney Somerville, an Indian of the Burnt Church Reserve, age 75, who has not been in good health for some time, recently suffered a stroke, which leaves him bed-fast, with practically no use of his legs. It is doubtful if he will last very long, and he wants his boys to come home from school at Shubenacadie. Mrs. Somerville says that the old man takes all her time, in looking after him, and she would like to have her older boy Herman, age 16, come home for a while, as she has a hard time getting along. No doubt this boy would be a help, in getting wood, and doing odd jobs around.

The Somerville boys have been at Shubenacadie for 8 years. The Railway fare from Shubenacadie to Newcastle, which is the nearest railway point to Burnt Church, is $8.65 single. I do not know what arrangements are made in matters of this nature, and would appreciate instructions from you as to whether or not you would advise the boys to leave the school; also, what arrangements are made concerning the fare if you will allow one or both of them to go home. In the past, I believe it was the policy of the Department, not to allow children to go home from school during the holidays, unless for a very serious reason.

I would appreciate your instructions in this matter, at your earliest convenience.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to the two Somerville boys who are pupils at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

Ernest Somerville is only 11 years of age, and from the information contained in your letter I cannot see much advantage in discharging him from the residential school.

Dear Sir:-

Albert Bernard, No. 206, has run away twice in the last ten days, and put us to plenty of trouble and expense. The young fellow is a first cousin of the Labobes, and like them, comes from P.E.I. The Labobes caused nothing but trouble and expense.

So we are taking this boy to Saint Patrick's Home tomorrow morning. All things considered, we think this is the only thing to do.

We hope the action will meet with your approval. We have had no runaways for two years, and we want to curb any such practice promptly. We are writing the Agent in P.E.I. informing him.

Yours very truly,

DATE Sept. 11th, 1941.

FILE REFERENCES

RE: Albert BERNARD - Trunacy - Indian Residential school, Shubenacadie, Hants Co., N.S.

HEADQUARTERS

1. The P.M., of this date, Father Mackey, Dpt., of the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S., reported that Albert BERNARD and Charles BERNARD, (subject of separate report) left the Institution.

SUB-DIVISION

2. Patrol was immediately made in P.C.R., S.S.S. to the Indian school, to obtain complete details and a full description of the missing boys.

DETACHMENT

3. A patrol of all roads leading out of Shubenacadie, was conducted by members of the Institution Staff. Members of the Farm Staff, accompanied by several of the older pupils were conducting a search of the surrounding woods and nearby premises.

P.C.R.

4. Chief Taylor, Stewiacke, N.S., was notified and given a brief description of the boys.

FIRST

5. Father Mackey requested that no action be taken by members of this Detachment until return of the posse which was searching the nearby woods, as he was under the impression that the boys were hiding in the immediate vicinity.

A.R.V. No.

6. Later, same date, patrol was made via private livery to Truro, accompanied by Father Mackey, following receipt of information that two Indian boys answering the description of those mentioned above, had been seen on the highway near Brookfield, N.S.

7. Extensive enquiries were made with negative results. The R.C.M., I.O., Truro Detachment was notified, and requested to maintain a watch on local patrols for the missing boys.

8. Shortly after the return of this patrol, Father Mackey notified this office that the missing boys had been located about ten miles down the Shubenacadie River, by the posse from the Indian School.

NO EXPENSES INCURRED:

The O.C., Halifax 3/Div., R.C.M. Police, Halifax, N.S. FORWARDED - 11-9-41.

Dear Sir:

We understand that it is your wish not to send children home for vacation when they have a long distance to travel. Our translation of the enclosed letter is that Agent Cyr wants the three Jacob children to go to Gaspe for vacation.

The mother of these children is dead, and the father, we understand is French, not Indian. The father has been going from pillar to post for years. His last stopping place was Cambridge, Nova Scotia. We understand from Agent Spinney that he was going to chase Jacobs away from the Cambridge Reserve. The old fellow passed through here about a week ago on his way to Quebec. Apparently, he went directly to the Agent and put up a good story.

Usually when an Agent asks for vacation for any children from his Agency, we are only too glad to send them, but this is a little out of the ordinary. Please let us know whether we should send the children or not.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of Sept. 26, 1941 I wish to say that in my opinion Mrs. Frank Paul is not in a position to provide for those two children and send them to school regularly.

In an interview with her recently she told me her husband was not very well and it was necessary for her to go out to work to help support the family. And she needed this girl to look after the house and care for the younger children. The boy was needed to assist in providing wood for fuel. You can readily understand what their helpful attendance would be liked.

I feel sure this family will have to have some relief assistance this winter regardless of whether the children are returned to the school or allowed to remain at home. I have talked to the children and they told me they did not want to go back.

Ottawa, October 28, 1941.

RE: Inspection at Maria Agency

I beg to report on my last inspection on the 21 and 22 instant to the above agency.

RELIEF

Owing to a number of rations being added on accounts, since last revision in June 1941, without any previous approval of this Department, I again revised the list and you will find annexed, the names cancelled, with remarks on each case. Total rations cancelled amount to $125.66 per month.

New lists were then prepared for each of the three approved merchants and copies left with the agent, with a letter of explanation and instructions. You will also find annexed, copies of such lists and letter.

This revision should take care of the relief required in the said agency. As a matter of fact, the Agent himself admitted some changes since we made drastic cuts in relief last January. The Indians appear to realize that it means business, and therefore, more of them have been going out to work than ever in the past.

RE: Peter Jacobs

Peter Jacobs was born at Guysboro N.S. He married at Buctouche, N.B., but had no children. A second marriage, at Richibucto, and five children were born, all of them died. He married a third time at Prince Edward Island, had five children; two died as well as the mother; the three living girls are: Sarah 16, Bertha 13, and Mary Laura 11.

He lived in many places and as a rolling stone, gathered no moss. He informed me that he had been living in the following places: Bathurst, N.B., 30 years; Ashland, Me., U.S.A., 7 years; Gaspe, P.Q., 1 year; Cambridge, N.S., a few months.

The man today is over seventy. The three girls have been staying at Shubenacadie School for some years, and this summer, the old man claimed them, pretending to be lonesome for them. He has been staying here and there at Maria Reserve, but Indians are getting fed up with him, as he is not a member of the Band; as a matter of fact he belongs to no band and has no house to live in, and there appears to be no permanent house on the reserve. The man impressed me as being of a demanding type of Indian, the kind who believes that we owe it all to him and is expecting to get it wherever he feels like living, without any effort on his part.

As to the girls, the oldest one is visiting here and there and appears to be free to go without much control; the second has poor eyesight, the father said that she received treatment while at Shubenacadie, but her eyes are getting worse all the time; as to the youngest, she stays also with her father who claims she is not properly dressed to go to school.

My suggestion that he go back where he was born, was turned down by the old man.

Before leaving, I authorized the Agent to give him light relief, until he is advised of the Department's decision on the case.
The agent informed me that he had notified the Shubenacadie School that Mr. Jacobs wanted his girls back with him and the School wired back to meet them the next day at Campbellton, N.B., but he did not go. However they were on the Reserve a few days later with their father.

I was told the night that I was surprised that he had not taken this matter up with the Department first, and he informed me that the former Agent, Mr. J. Adhemar Cyr, told him all he had to do was to notify the school and they would let the girls go.

Although not familiar with proceedings in such cases, I thought that so long as the Department had placed the children in the school and paid for their upkeep, it was only fair that the Department should be consulted in such cases previous to taking the children out.

Mr. Napoleon Cyr was told that in future, he should be careful to consult the Department, in matters of which he was in doubt, in preference to any one else.

Jude Thibault
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Quebec Inspectorate.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 10th instant with reference to the Jacobs girls. The information contained in Constable Gideon's letter is the same as that which we received from Mr. Thibault, Inspector of Indian Agencies for the Province of Quebec, who visited the Maria Reserve recently.

Indian Agent Cyr had no authority to write to you in the manner he did last June. The father of the Jacobs girls is in no position to support them and they should have been left in the Shubenacadie School. We have made inquiries but find it impossible to place them in an institution near the reserve. I presume that under these circumstances you will be prepared to accept them again and instructions are being issued to have them returned to Shubenacadie at an early date.

It is quite possible that the re-admission of these children will bring the total pupilage at this school over the number for which grant is allowed. However, we will adjust this when paying the March quarter per capita allowance and at that time we will provide supernumerary grant if your returns for the December and March quarter show that such action is necessary.

Dear Sir:

In a letter dated June 25 last you directed the Principal of the Shubenacadie Residential School to return Sarah, Bertha and Mary Laura Jacobs. As a result of this letter the children were sent home to the father and we are now informed that he is unable to properly look after them.

You should, therefore, make immediate arrangements to return the children to the Shubenacadie School and payment of their transportation from Campbellton to Shubenacadie will be made on receipt from you of a properly certified account in triplicate.

I would also direct your attention to the fact that you have no authority to authorize discharge of children from residential schools. Very serious consideration was given to deducting the cost of their transportation from your salary. However, it has been decided not to take such action this time but if there is any recurrence of this matter the amount of expense involved will be so deducted.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir,

I am taking the liberty to write to the Department in order to explain regarding myself, my two sisters and father. I am the eldest daughter, being on 16 and at present on service for a family on Maria Reserve. My father and 2 youngest sisters are at present on this Reserve, not having a home here or and no home on the Cambridge Reserve. The Department shall be & make it compulsory to have my sisters returned to the school at Indian Residential School Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia, trusting that the Department will take immediately action. Yours Truly,

Dear Mr. Phelan:

The two young girls are still here and the case is now complicated. I wonder if it is wise under the circumstances to send them to Nova Scotia. The Indian constable Milton Gordon has statements from the above mentioned girls that Anthony Martin, an Indian 75 years old, has been acting in an indecent manner with them. This apparently has been going on for some time. The father and the children had been living with this old man. At present these girls are with a respectable family.

The case is now in the hands of the Provincial Police and there seems to be nothing can be done till the investigation has taken place. Agent Cyr is reporting fully on the case.

If there is anything I can do, wire me care of Dr. Richard. I will be there till Saturday.

Yours truly,

We have a letter from the Department, dated September 21st, File 51-0-10, in which Bernice and three others are discharged. Do not do anything further about sending her back until you hear again from the Department.

We wrote to the Department on September 12th, giving them the names and numbers of those who did not return to school. At the same time we requested the discharge of four who were well under sixteen years of age, and gave the reasons for our request. The letter from the Department, dated September 21st, approved the discharge of those whom we had requested.

We will send to the Department a copy of this letter.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of January 6th, concerning No. 69 James Prosper. By the time he finished Grade 8 work, he was not sixteen years of age. The next term, we sent him to the school in the village, to attend Grade 9. At the close of the school term, he led the boys in the class, and was second in the whole class, one girl having higher marks than he had. It was during that year that we had the permission of the Department to send him to High School. During the next year, he held his place, and the last report for Grade XI, he was leading the class, having finally caught up with the girl who had previously led.

As far as we know, at the present time, when he finished Grade XI he intended to try for the Air Force. He will be eighteen on February 10th. He is an illegitimate child; we understand that the mother is now married to a white man. We do not remember any of his people ever coming to see him, and he doesn't hear from any of them by letter.

No. 665, Mary Clare, is an orphan, and has always been a delicate child. When about fifteen years old, she developed a sort of fainting spell. After observation at the Victoria General Hospital in Halifax, they seemed to think there was pressure felt the brain. They recommended that she be taken to certain brain specialists in Montreal. The department concurred and advised us that she should go, and have a companion, to Montreal. When the word came, the youngster said that she would not go, as she hoped to die here. She is not on the same routine as the others. She seems to know when the attack is coming on, and she goes to bed, and rests, with perhaps a little bromide. She has not had any attack now for at least six months. We doubt very much if she could go out
go out and earn her own living, for any length of time. However, if you think that she should be discharged, we could find out from the Agent if he could find a suitable place for her. She was eighteen in October, and we would like to see her remain here until she is twenty years old.

No. 229, Roland Patrick Peters, comes from P.E.I. and he has been here since September 8th. We will write to Agent Jaly, and have him forward the form, "Application for Admission."

Yours very truly,

Dear Sirs,

I herewith make application to you for the return of my three children—Rita, Mary B., and Eugene—who are now inmates of the Indian school at Shubenacadie. The oldest is 12 and the youngest only 7. They are too young to be away from their parents, and my wife is fretting about them.

When they went to the school last fall I signed a paper. Just lately I was told that in that paper I agreed to let them stay at the school until they are 16. I did not understand that when I signed the paper; I just wanted them to have a chance to learn English.

We have a good school at Afton and I am able to support the children, and both myself and my wife would like to have the little ones home again. Please permit us to take the children home.

March 5, 1943.

Mr. J. A. MacLean,
Indian Agent,
Eskasoni Chapel, N.S.

Dear Mr. MacLean:

In reply to your letter of March 3rd, concerning the possibility of Mary Julia Michael, going to live with Michael R. Denny.

This girl will be sixteen years old on December 10th, 1943. Under ordinary circumstances, this girl would be discharged from the school at the close of this term, on June 30th. But, in view of the fact that she is an orphan, and very small for her age, we think it best to refer the matter to the Department. From your letter, we would judge that the home conditions of Mr. Denny are not suitable.

By April 1st, we hope to furnish you with a list of those from your district who ordinarily would be discharged this year. This will give you time to look over the situation for each individual, and let us know whether they should be discharged or not. It would be a help to both of us if we also make a list of those going home for vacation, but who would be expected back to school by September 1st.

If you have any children there, whom you think should be here, will you please let us know not later than mid-summer.

Hoping you are making good progress, and that we shall have the pleasure of meeting you soon,

Yours very truly,

Dear Mr. Whalen:-

Further regarding our truant pupil, Joyce Sapier (Meuse), who gave us so much trouble during the first part of this term.

Joyce attended school on an average of five days a month during the quarter ending March 31st. She is in Maine, U.S.A., at present, but is liable to return at any time and I would strongly recommend that, if she return, she be sent to Shubenacadie. She is only thirteen, but is quite tough, as you know. Her mother is irresponsible and not only allows Joyce to run the streets and roads at night and sleep until noon, but rather encourages it.

As I feel the girl needs supervision and I have done everything possible, I shall be glad if you will take this up with the Department for her sake, as well as the example to the other children.

Yours sincerely,

Regina McElligott.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Canada.

The above named girl who is an illegitimate child of Mrs. William Meuse, would not go to school and was very saucy with the teacher. When her mother, who always backs her, received a warning regarding this girl's truancy, she had the grandmother, who resides in Maine, take the girl to her place. Last week the mother and father also moved to Maine, therefore I do not expect Joyce to return for sometime, however if she does, and gives us trouble, I would recommend that she be sent to Shubenacadie for her own good as well as an example to the others.

Edward J. Whalen.
Indian Agent

Shall we give these new numbers, or retain the old ones?
We shall notify the Agents about these children who have not returned, and request that they be returned to the school as soon as possible. A word from you would help a lot.

Agent Rice interviewed Mr. and Mrs. Knockwood, parents of No. 195 Noel Knockwood. Among other things, he was told by Mr. Knockwood that no one was going to tell him what he was to do with his children. The mother brought back the two girls, Imbell and Rosie, but the father says that the boy can go to the day school, on the Reserve, and, in fact, he has already been at the day school. We are of the opinion that the teacher there, knowing that this boy was registered here, should not have accepted him, without a discharge from the Residential School.

A few days ago we received a list of names from Agent MacLean, thirty-two in all. Application for eight have already been made to the Department. However, in talking to Miss Gallagher, teacher of the Indian School at Sydney, she said that she had recommended thirteen of those thirty-two names, but, on learning of conditions here, she would say that six of the thirteen should come here, if possible.

Again, the Island, P.E.I., are up to their old tricks. Half-past one, on the afternoon of September 1st, we had a telephone call from Agent Daley, that seven were on the way. He could not hear a word that I was saying, so he said, but I don't believe he wanted to hear anything. A Quarter of twelve that night, these seven new ones arrived with those coming back from vacation. We hope that you have the applications for them, but we doubt it.

As our Quota has been reduced to 148, we do not, under present conditions, feel like taking many more than that number. However, we will look things over, and recommend as many as possible of those on Mr. MacLean's list.

Yours very truly,

With reference to pupils 138, 215, 0176 and 0203, they should retain their old numbers. As requested, the Indian Agents concerned are being written regarding pupils who have not returned. I am also writing the Indian Agent at Prince Edward Island again, pointing out to him that children should not be sent to the Shubenacadie School from that agency unless he has previously forwarded the applications to this office and received approval.

Ottawa,
September 13, 1943.

Mr. J.A. MacLean, Indian Agent, Eskasoni Chapel, N.S.

I am in receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant, enclosing applications for the admission of 24 children to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. I visited this school recently and found that, owing to many demands for admission, it will not be possible to accept all the children whose applications you forwarded. I am advising Rev. J.P. Mackey, the Principal, to communicate with you and advise how many of the number mentioned he can accept. It will probably be about 8. In that event you should select those whose home conditions are unsuitable, or who are not residing close to an Indian day school.

Peter J. Gould, No. 136, and Eva Morris, No. 0187, who were allowed home on leave, have not yet been returned to the school. Accommodation is being reserved for these two children and they should be returned immediately. If they are not physically fit, you should advise Father Mackey, in order that he may allot their accommodation to other applicants.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
September 13, 1943.

Mr. J.E. Daly, Indian Agent, Charlottetown, P.E.I.

I understand that you recently sent seven children to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School without first forwarding their applications for our consideration and without being advised that accommodation was available for them. It is difficult for the Department to understand why you have overlooked specific instructions given to you regarding the admission of children to Shubenacadie. Please forward the usual forms for our consideration and at the same time you should definitely note that in future no children should be sent to the Shubenacadie School from Prince Edward Island unless you have submitted the applications to this office and you have received formal permission for their admission to the school.

Eva Tuplin, No. 0131, Olive Tuplin, No. 0149, Denzil Feehan, No. 156, Roland Peters, No. 229 and Leo Peters, No. 193, who were allowed home on leave, had not returned to the school on September 7, on which date I was at the school. You should arrange for their return immediately but, if they are not physically fit or you do not consider it advisable to return them for some other reason, you should advise this office at once.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Fredericton, Sept. 20, 1943.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

We have rather a strange case at the present time. One of two children, Mary Ann Sebattis, Age 8 and her sister Rose Marie, Age 6.

These children were borne on the Oromocto Reserve, to Mr & Mrs Louis Sebattis.

On August 6, 1941 Louis Sebattis died, and on April 11, 1942 his widow married Albert Herbert McCoy, a white man on the Killarney Road, about two miles from F'nton. She took her two children to live with her.

On Sept 9, 1943 Mrs McCoy, mother of the children, died and their foster father, McCoy, does not wish to look after the children. He says he has so many bills to look after that he cannot keep house and is obliged to go to the woods to work. He also said that the children are Indians and he feels they should be looked after by the Indian Affairs Branch where they would be with their own.

I told Mr McCoy it was rather a strange case and I would have to take it up with the Department before I could take any steps, but I would write to them and let him know as soon as I had a reply.

If these children are to be looked after by the Department I would recommend that they be placed in the Residential School at Shubenacadie as the Mc Coys are of a very low class and I would like to get the children away from them if we were to look after their welfare.

Would you please advise the Departments wishes at an early date.

Edward J. Whalen.

AIR MAIL

Dear Father Mackey:

I was somewhat disappointed to learn from your telegram of September 22 that you found it impossible to provide accommodation for Joseph Johnston, the pupil on whose behalf I communicated with you a few days ago.

Dr. Moore, our Acting Superintendent of Medical Services, has been notified by the hospital authorities in Montreal that this boy must be removed from the institution at once, as their capacity is taxed to the utmost. Dr. Moore has been in communication with the Indian Agent and has not succeeded at this date in securing an Indian who would be willing to provide this boy with board and lodging. As a matter of fact so many of our Indians are gainfully employed that they are not willing, for the time being at least, to assume such responsibilities.

In addition to the case of Joseph Johnston, we are in receipt of a letter from the Indian Agent at Fredericton, in which he states that Mary Ann Sebattis, age 5, and her sister, Rose Marie, age 6, are urgently in need of institutional care. The Agent in his letter states:

"On August 8, 1941, Louis Sebattis died and on April 11, 1942, his widow married Albert Herbert McCoy, a white man on the Killarney Road about two miles from Fredericton. She took her two children to live with her. On September 9, 1943, Mrs. McCoy, mother

Rev. J.P. Mackey,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.
of the children, died and their foster father, McCoy, does not wish to look after the children. He has stated that the children are Indians and he feels they should be looked after by the Indian Affairs Branch."

I am of the opinion that these orphan children have a peculiar claim upon the Department and I have been wondering if it would not be possible to make provision for these three children at Shubenacadie, even though you had to discharge three of the senior pupils. I am communicating with you by air mail and would appreciate an immediate reply. We are making provision for the board and lodging of Joseph Johnston in Montreal until we hear from you.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

The story behind the discharge of No. 023, Bernadette Prosper, 024 Rita Prosper, and 225, Eugene Prosper, is that the father of these children occasionally goes on a big time. About a year ago, the mother approached the Agent about sending them to school here. Apparently, the mother signed the papers unknown to the father. He in turn became very nasty about it, so much so, that during the year the mother had a nervous breakdown. Finally the mother came here wanting to know if they could be kept home this year.

Under the circumstances we listed them as discharged, after only one year here.

Yours very truly,

November 25, 1943.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Dear Sir:

Beg to inform you that sometime between midnight and two A.M. Thursday, the 11th of this month, three boys managed to get out of the house.

John Thomas....No. 147
Harry Sark 154
William Copage 196

John Thomas was the leader of this trio. It is the second time this year that he has been involved in the same kind of thing. Previous to this, he made a key to fit all the doors, got up during the night, and visited the storerooms. He made a second key, unlocked the dormitory and outside doors, took the two younger boys with him, as well as a supply of food and blankets, and was missed at five A.M. We immediately notified Mr. Rice and the R.C.M.P. and they were able to pick up William Copage on Saturday, in Antigonish, and Harry Sark Sunday, in Mulgrave. Today, John Thomas is back again at the school, having been located at Antigonish. After talking the matter over with Mr. Rice, we decided that the best place for this boy is Saint Patrick's Home, in Halifax, and we are sending him there tomorrow morning. We hope that this action will meet with your approval.

Yours very truly,

P.S. Since writing the above, John Thomas made another getaway. We planned on having him locked up with the R.C.M.P. tonight, and in the meantime, had him locked in the dormitory, on the top floor. He managed to get out the window by means of the fire hose, and at the present time, Mr. Rice, the R.C.M.P., and all concerned are scouring the neighborhood for him. This time he was missed within ten minutes, but it is after dark.
Ottawa,
November 29, 1943.

Reverend Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th instant, in which you report regarding the truancy of pupils 147, 154 and 196. I trust that by this time you have located John Thomas, No. 147, and have him safely placed in St. Patrick's Home, Halifax.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

A request was made to meet the car from Shubenacadie, N.S. and same was met at Alton, N.S. where THOMAS was handed over to the N.C.O. I/C Shubenacadie Detachment and the Indian Agent.

This date, following receipt of a telephone message from Mr. H. C. Rice, Indian Agent, Shubenacadie, to the effect that one, John Thomas, an escaped pupil from the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie was in Antigonish and he wished someone to accompany him to escort the child back as Father Mackey, Superintendent of the School, was ill patrol was made to Antigonish in company with Mr. Rice via private car.

THOMAS was escorted back to the Indian School at Shubenacadie via private car.

Mr. Rice called this office about two hours later and reported THOMAS as being absent again.

Truro Detachment and Chief of Police Taylor at Stewiacke were immediately notified to be on a watch for the truant.

Local patrols were made in P/O 8323 and trains in the District were checked.

In the early A.M. of this date Truro Detachment reported an Indian boy had been located by C. N. R. Police on Railway property.

It was established that the boy was none other than THOMAS.

Mr. Rice was notified and stated that he had not been able to have his car repaired and further requested that this Force return the boy from Truro.

Patrol was made to Alton in P/O 8323 accompanied by R. McKinnon, Clerk of the local Indian Department, and THOMAS taken in custody from a patrol out of Truro Detachment.

THOMAS was returned to Shubenacadie in P/O 8323 and lodged in the Detachment cell until morning when he was escorted to St. Patrick's Home, Halifax, by Father Mackey, Supt., of the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, and Mr. H. C. Rice, Indian Agent.

On or about January 22nd-44 I received a letter from Rev. Fr. Smith, P.P. at Amherst, N.S. in which he reported to me some alleged mistreatment of a 12 year old Indian child. This child, Rita Bernard, was staying with her elder brother William Bernard at Oxford Jct., Cumb. Co., N.S. Her parents were both dead and the family were scattered. His information came from the wife of the Chief of this band and he asked me to investigate.

I arranged with Rev. Fr. Brown for her admittance to the Residential School and sent Wm. Bernard the necessary form to have completed. He declined to send her at the time. On April 25th I received another letter from a merchant, Mrs Rogers of Oxford Jct. written on behalf of Rita, and, at her request, In this letter Rita complained of being mistreated, overworked, kept from school, etc and asked that I come up and take her away. A few days later I received another from Rita herself asking to be taken away from her brother's wife as quickly as possible. In the meantime I had acknowledged Mrs. Roger's letter stating that I would go up on May 3rd to investigate and take whatever action I thought necessary.

On the 3rd inst. I took with me a member of the R.C.M.P. detachment at Springhill and called on all parties concerned. I met Mrs. Rogers who told me that she believed Rita's story as she was quite familiar with Mrs. Bernard. Rita had been expecting me and expressed a desire to go at once to the Res. School. I went to interview Mrs. Bernard and found her absent picking Mayflowers. I also met with Rita's teacher who stated that she thought the Residential School was the best place for her and in view of all the evidence I left a note for Mrs. Bernard stating that I was taking the child with me to the school in Shubenacadie. The R.C.M.P. concurred with me and consequently I placed Rita in the Res. School on May 3rd.
I might mention that whenever Mr. & Mrs. Bernard were away from home simultaneously the child was left with an old blind Indian. On one occasion both this couple were arrested for being intoxicated and while serving their time Rita was again left with this old blind man.

In view of the fact that Rita's older brothers and sisters were not capable of looking after her, the one of them now, Reggie, is serving a 3 mos. jail sentence in Truro, that another, Annabel, is an immoral young woman working in and around Halifax, I consider that the school is the only satisfactory environment for this child, for the next four or five years.

H. C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

I hereby acknowledge receipt of your letter of May 30, re Dr White's letter recommending the discharge of Teresa Ginish.

Dr White is very kind to the Indians and I am sure that he wrote this letter to please Mrs Isobel Ginish, mother of this child who is trying to get her out of the school, rather than according to his ideas.

At any rate I am not in accord with Dr White and would strongly recommend that this girl, Teresa, be left in the school rather than be allowed to go to her mother who is living with a white man, Mr Smith, of Dunsinene.

There are no Indians living at Dunsinene now and the transient ones who might come there during the summer are not of the kind a girl 15 years old should be with.

Unless otherwise instructed I will not write to the school asking for the release of Teresa Ginish.

I have your letter of the 6th instant, with reference to the request for the discharge of Teresa Ginish from the Shubenacadie Residential School. In view of the information contained in your letter the Department feels that this girl should remain in the school.

There is a new Principal at Shubenacadie and it is just possible that if the mother writes direct to him the discharge might be allowed before we were consulted. During the last week of April the R.C.M.P. took action against Mrs. Stephen Bartlett an Indian of Yarmouth band. This did not go to court but resulted in her two minor children being escorted to the Residential school on the first day of May. I later requested the assistance of this force to remove from the Yarmouth reservation an unwanted trespasser who reputedly held a liquor permit and was bringing intoxicants on the reserve. He left the reserve before their arrival but they are watching for his return. I went personally to Cumberland County and took a child, who was being abused by her guardians, back with me to the Residential school. In the past month there was only one conviction to my knowledge and the Indian concerned paid a ten dollar fine for assault. Luckily this case was tried in a police court in Halifax where it was not known that the accused was under a one years suspended sentence for the same offence.

H.C. Rice,
Agent.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Re: Mary Clare, No. 0185

We have a request from the Department asking for an explanation of this girl's case. We did not include her in with the list of those eligible for discharge this year, but we find that in looking over our files, we mentioned her last year, and received permission to keep her. We should have mentioned her this year.

Perhaps you recall the case. Father Mackey called this girl over, and you spoke to her on your visit to the school last year. The Department gave permission a few years ago for this girl to go to Montreal for an operation, but the girl herself did not want it. She was taking fits, similar to epileptic fits, and if she were discharged from the school, would not be able to support herself, and the Department would have had to find a home, and pay her board.

However, in view of the fact that she has not taken one of these turns for over a year now, perhaps the Department wishes her discharge. If so, we shall try to get in touch with her relatives. She has no parents, but has an Aunt, in Red Bank, N.B.

Please let us know what you wish done in this case.

Yours very truly,

REVEREND J.W. BROWN, Principal.

Mr. J.A. MacLean, Indian Agent, Eskasoni Chapel, N.S.

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of 13 children to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. It is noted that all these children come from reserves where day schools are located. You show on the application forms that both parents of all these children are living, with the exception of the three Françoise children, whose mother is dead. We are prepared to approve the admission to the Shubenacadie School of Louise, Mary and Benjamin Françoise. With regard to the others we would like to know if there are any special reasons why these children should receive institutional care. When the parents are able to support their children and they reside on a reserve where a day school is being operated it is not the general practice of the Department to send such children to a residential school. We are endeavouring to reserve the accommodation at Shubenacadie for orphan and neglected children.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Re: Family of Sylvester Sabattis, Oromocto, N.B.

Enclosed you will find a letter which I received from Miss Delaney, school teacher of the Oromocto Indian School. I knew this family would require attention, but I had been trying to keep the father interested in his children and encourage him to look after them. I knew they were not getting 100% care, but I don't think things were as bad as they appear in the letter. The family received an allowance monthly, and the father worked quite regularly with Mr. Bridges of Majerville, a market gardener.

He had worked there for a number of years and came home nights. This past year, however, he stayed away a lot and was boarding in a camp with a George Nash, a half-breed who worked for the same man. The two got drinking, according to Mr. Bridges and became no good, so he discharged them. Since that time, Sylvester Sabattis had been slipping and lost interest in his home and children.

I stopped his allowance August 1st, and gave the girl, age 9, to John S. Paul to look after at $2.00 a week, and the boy, age 4, to John M. Paul at $2.00 a week. The oldest girl was away staying with her uncle, William Meuse, and the two boys I left with the father. I was in hopes he would straighten up and ask for the children and his allowance again, but he has now gone to Maine and left them behind.

I feel the best place for the three children, Harry, Stephen and Lillian, is Shubenacadie School, and to that end, I have had them examined and am forwarding application forms for their admission, should room be available at the school.

p.t.e.
As stated above, the father is away in Maine and cannot be contacted to sign the application forms. However, according to Miss Delaney's letter, he is willing for them to go.

I am now boarding these children at $2.00 a week in Indian homes, and would ask for authority to leave Jesse Robert, age 4, at John M. Paul's, as he is too young to go to Shubenacadie, rate - $2.00 weekly in groceries, and clothing periodically.

Mr. E.J. Whalen, Indian Agent, Fredericton, N.B.

In my letter of the 19th instant I informed you that we had no record of the application forms for the admission of the Lafferty children to the Shubenacadie Residential School. In conversation with Doctor Falconer this morning I find that the application forms for Harold and Henry reached the office but were placed on the medical file. I was at the Shubenacadie School about ten days ago and at that time they appeared to have their full quota of pupils. However, I am writing to the Principal today advising him that we feel that these two boys should receive institutional care and suggesting to him that even though they have their full quota the boys be accepted as supernumerary pupils. I suggest that you also write to the Principal and he will give you his decision. If the boys could not be placed in the Shubenacadie School is there any white institution in which accommodation could be secured for them.

Philip Phelan,

Reverend Sir:

The Department is in receipt of applications for the admission of Harold and Henry Lafferty of Kings County, New Brunswick, to the Shubenacadie School. These two boys require institutional care at the earliest possible date. I remember that you were under the impression that you had your full quota of pupils. However, as this is such a deserving case I thought it advisable to bring the matter to your attention and I trust that you will be able to provide accommodation for them. If necessary we will allow supernumerary grant for these two boys. I am suggesting to the Indian Agent, Mr. E.J. Whelan, Fredericton, New Brunswick, that he communicate with you and, if you accept these boys, you should advise Mr. Whelan so that he can bring them to the school.

As there is no day school for these children to attend and as their father is an active case of Pulmonary T.B., and as this entire family are supported by relief, it is imperative that these children be returned here, for adequate food, clothing, health, etc.

I interviewed this woman and ordered the children back. She became insolent and very uncooperative. I advised her that I would call for her children and to have them ready Monday Morning, September 16th. You will notice Stephen Sabattis, Age 12, is not mentioned as one of the children taken to Shubenacadie, October 2nd, although he was to have gone.

This boy, also his sister Lillian, went to Maine with an Indian family September 19th as they did not want to go to the residential school. When I heard this I made inquiries as to where they went and learned they were in Hodgson, Maine. On September 22nd I went to Hodgson and got these two children. I warned them to stay on the Creemecte Reserve as I expected word to take them at any time and I wanted them handy when the time came to go. Lillian remained as instructed but Stephen broke into his uncle's house stole a bicycle and left the Reserve September 27th. This was not reported to me until Sept 30th, when I immediately notified the R.C.M.P. Police. As Stephen was not located on October 2nd and I had planned on taking the children that day I took the other four.

I learned this morning that Stephen Sabattis is at Gagetown with his aunt Mrs Jim Nash. Mr Nash told me he was willing to take the boy and try to do something with him as he had been neglected by the father. Nash told me he has settled for the bicycle that had been stolen and if I was willing he would send the boy to school. I told him I was quite willing but would report the case to Ottawa.

Tom Nash is a halfbreed and has been living around Gagetown for a great many years. He has no status as an Indian but seems to be quite prosperous and I think if he can manage this boy, will give him a good home.

May I have your comments please.

Edward J. Whalen,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, October 12, 1944.

Mr. Edward J. Whalen, Indian Agent, Fredericton, N. B.

Re: Stephen Sabattis.

I have for acknowledgment your letter of October 9 and have noted with interest the information contained therein.

It would appear that this boy has a good home for the time being and the inclination of the Department at the moment is not to disturb him. This boy, in our judgment, however, will require careful watching, and you should receive from time to time a report on his attendance at school and his general conduct. Should he show a tendency toward waywardness at any time, he should be sent either to the Shubenacadie Residential School or to a correctional institution.

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

On October 2nd., accompanied by my wife as a matron, I left by car, for Shubenacadie to take Lillian and Harry Sabbatis, Cremecto reserve also Harold and Henry Lafferty of Fairvale Station to the Indian Residential School.

I had sent word to the Lafferty family, Mrs Lafferty, to have her children ready and at the Post Office - Fairvale Station. When I arrived at this place there was no sign of the Lafferty children and I was obliged to go to their camp about 1½ miles in the woods. On my arrival I found Mrs Lafferty washing the clothes the children were to wear. This delay caused us to have to stop all night on the way. (Derchester N.B.)

On the morning of October 3rd before we arrived at Truro, N.S. I had a blow out which ruined one of my synthetic tires and I was obliged to purchase a new one. The time spent in getting authority to buy this tire delayed us so much that my wife and I were obliged to remain another night on the return trip. (Truro)

We returned to Fredericton Wednesday evening, October 4th.

In my last report I spoke of an epidemic of beer-making on a number of reserves. As usual I requested the assistance of the R.C.M.P., which resulted in five arrests on liquor charges. Ruddie KNOCKWOOD (Indian) Escaped Boy from the Shubenacadie Indian School, Shubenacadie, N.S. (Asst. to Indian Dept.)

1. At 8:30 A.M., this date, Father Brown, Supt., of the Shubenacadie Indian School telephoned to the effect that four of his Indian boys had escaped from the Institution during the night, and that a checkup has failed to reveal their whereabouts. He and the Indian Agent, Mr. C. Rice, requested our assistance.

2. These Indian boys are described as follows:
   (1) Peter SAPPIER, mother residing at the Caribou Indian Reserve in Maine. Age 14 yrs, very fair, tall & slim. Heavy black shoes, blue bib overalls, black jackets, light cotton shirt. Fur lined cloth caps with ear flaps.
   (2) John Gilbert JULIEN, parents at Bayfield, N.S. Very dark skin, very sore eyes. Two front upper teeth missing. Age 14 yrs, black hair, short & stocky. Dressed as SAPPIER.
   (3) Preston COPAGE, father at Shubenacadie Indian Reserve. Age 14 yrs, auburn hair, pug nose, short & stocky. Companion to SAPPIER and may go with him to Cambridge, N.S. Dressed same.
   (4) Ruddie KNOCKWOOD, family at Pictou Landing, N.S. Age 13 yrs, fair, blue eyes, very long thin and narrow face. Short and slim build. Dressed same as SAPPIER.

3. Enquiries made revealed that these boys had been at the Railway Station at Stewiacke, N.S., during the early hours of the morning, and not seen again. It is assumed that they secured a ride on a freight going through, either to Halifax or in the direction of Truro, N.S.

4. The Truro and New Glasgow Detachments were advised by telephone to be on the lookout for these Indian boys.

5. A few hours after receipt of this complaint, a telephone call was received by the Indian Agent from Mr. Wallace of Wolfville, N.S., to the effect that he was holding three Indian boys who refuse to give their names and whom he suspects are from the Shubenacadie Indian School. Further enquiries made by the Indian Agent and Fr. Brown identified these three Indian boys to be SAPPIER, JULIEN and COPAGE. They were subsequently returned to the School by the Indian Agent.

6. Ruddie KNOCKWOOD is still at large and believed to be at or around his home in the Pictou Landing district. This boy did not take the same train as the other three, who took a freight to Halifax and then the D.A.R. out, and enroute to Cambridge were held aboard the train by the Conductor who handed them over to the Wolfville Town Police.

7. In view of the above, it is requested that enquiries be made in the Pictou Landing district by the Detachment concerned.

8. Extra copies attached.

9. STILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

Reference your letter No. 51-0-10, dated November 22, regarding the children of the above named Indian and giving details regarding the procedure to be taken, we have acted as per your instructions and settled the matter to our satisfaction.

Dear Father Brown:

Early in December we received a report from the R.C.M.P. with reference to action they were taking to apprehend Ruddie Knockwood, who had truanted from the Shubenacadie Residential School. Apparently the information given to the police was that the boy came from the vicinity of Pictou Landing. On making inquiries they ascertained that he only remained at Pictou Landing for a day and then proceeded, with his older brother Albert, to Portland, Maine, where his father, Joseph Knockwood, is employed in the shipyards. Subsequently it was learned that Knockwood had relatives living at Lennox Island. The police made inquiries there and were very definitely informed that he was not on the Lennox Island Reserve.

I thought you would like to have the above information, as you may not receive copies of the police report.

Ottawa, January 17, 1945.

Dear Father Brown:

With reference to your telegram of the 16th instant, I enclose original application form for the admission of Roderick Knockwood to the Shubenacadie Residential School. When you obtain the information you desire, it would be appreciated if you would return the form to this office.

Mr. Hoey and I have discussed this case today, and it is quite similar to several cases we have had at other Indian residential schools throughout Canada within the last few months. We have been adopting the attitude that unless the circumstances are very exceptional there is not much advantage in going to a great deal of expense in returning boys of this age who have truanted. It is very unlikely that they would be satisfied if they were brought back, and if this supposition is correct they would be a constant source of trouble to the school staff and, in addition would have a bad effect on general discipline. This applies particularly where the boy has gone out of the country. In the present case, as stated in my letter of the 4th instant, our information is to the effect that the father is working in the State of Maine. It is presumed that he is able to keep the boy and I do not feel that there is any particular advantage in spending considerable funds in returning him to Shubenacadie at the present time. As you know, the R.C.M. Police are extremely co-operative with us, but the expense they incur in returning truant pupils is a charge against this Branch.

If the boy returns to Canada within the

Reverend J. W. Brown,
Principal,

Shubenacadie, N.S., January 16, 1945.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Sometime during the night of Friday, November 24th, 1944, four youths ran away from the Residential School. Three were picked up shortly in Wolfville, N.S., and the fourth, Roddie MacLeod of Pictou Landing, N.S., remained at large, whereabouts unknown. The RCMP Police have been looking for this boy and recently Mr. Brown was advised that he was picked up by the police in the city of Portland, Maine, U.S.A., and placed in some parochial school there.

The Principal of the School, Rev. Mr. Brown, considers this boy to be the ring-leader and chiefly responsible for the run-away incident. He feels that he should be brought back to the School. Before leaving he broke into the store-room and stole numerous articles. Mr. Brown's opinion is that he should be made to come back for the principle of the thing at least for a time and if necessary he could be placed in St. Patrick's Home, a boy's reformatory operated by the Christian Brother's, in Halifax, N.S.

His suggestion is that I go to Portland, at his expense and personally escort the boy back. I am willing to do this and he suggested that since the week of Jan 22nd is most suitable for all concerned I should proceed there then.

I would be away for about three days and all expenses incurred would be taken care of by the Principal. Please advise, airmail, if this action on my part would meet with your approval.

H. C. Rice,
Indian Agent.
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, January 19, 1945.

Mr. H. C. Rice, Indian Agent, Shubenacadie, N. S.

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant, I am enclosing copy of a letter sent to Reverend Father Brown, dated January 17. This letter is self-explanatory, as you will notice. There is but one point in favour of bringing this boy back and that would be on the plea that the example given might be conducive to the delinquency of others. However, I believe that the disadvantages greatly outweigh this point. The possibility of that example can be obviated by certain steps and instructions to the other pupils in the school. Therefore, I do not think it is advisable for you to take this trouble and for the school to incur this expense.

Encl.

Acting Director.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Many thanks for your letter of Wednesday. Roderick Knockwood is at present in Portland, Maine, living with his father, who is working in the shipyards earning good money, and able to support him.

Our only motive in bringing him back was to convince the others that no one could just walk out and stay; that we would, at any cost, bring them back. I understand that the boy would still want to get away, and might not be satisfied here. Since he is not returned, I think others will try in the Spring.

However, since your decision is at hand, that closes Roderick's case, unless we hear of his returning to Pictou Landing. We are enclosing "Application Form" for your files, and very many thanks.

Best wishes from "We Indians" for 1945!

Sincerely yours,

At 10:45 P.M. this date, Father Brown, Supt., of the Shubenacadie Indian School telephoned this office to the effect that one of their girls, the above named, had escaped from the institution at about 9:15 P.M. by crawling through a window of the dormitory. It is believed that she was attempting to make her way to Truro and then to Pistou Landing, her former home.

Father Brown is of the opinion that this escape was pre-arranged and that possibly some one with a car was to wait at some point, as it has since been learned that the father, Joseph Knockwood, Portland, Maine, has been endeavouring to get his family together into Maine. Recently one of this girl's brothers, Eddie Knockwood, escaped from this school and is now with his father. Div. File M-H-1278-3-4.

Description of the above named girl as follows; Age 15 years, would pass for a girl of 17 years, light copper colour. Black hair with a permanent wave. Round full face and black eyes. Her wearing apparel at the time was, Blue ski jacket & Wine colour ski pants.

On receipt of above and request of Father Brown and the Indian Agent, a patrol was made from this Detachment and the road leading to Truro checked, also the railway station at Shubenacadie, Quinbrook and Truro, without finding any trace of this Indian girl. The Hill Brook Indian Settlement at Truro was checked in the meantime by the Indian Chief resident there, without results.

This date, the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve was checked by the Writer and Sgt. Harris, as it was thought that possibly this girl would go there and stay with friends for a time. From reliable sources it was learned that she did not visit the Reserve.

Two sisters of this girl reside on the Pistou Landing Reserve, namely, Mrs. Martin Francis and Mrs. Sepier. It is very likely that this girl will go to one of these homes. In view of this, Father Brown called the New Glasgow Detachment and requested their assistance in this matter.

In view of the above, extra copy of this report has been forwarded direct to the W.O.O. in Charge, New Glasgow Detachment.

WILL UNDER INVESTIGATION.

Indian Affairs Branch, OTTAWA.

Re Hazel Knockwood, Indian Residential School.

On the eve of February 17th the above mentioned Indian girl, pupil at the Residential School, left that institution on or about 6.30 P.M.

Her absence was noted within an hour or less and the Principal, Rev. J. W. Brown, notified the R.C.M.P., myself and then requested the railway police to be on the look-out for her. Nothing further was heard of this girl and it looked as if this runaway had been well planned as she seemed to disappear altogether.

Four days later word was received that there was an Indian girl hiding in a small white settlement between Shubenacadie and Stewiacke, no more than 3 miles from the School. The R.C.M.P. investigated and picked up the girl returning her to the school.

The girl is a sister of Roddie Knockwood the boy who made a recent escape and joined his family in Maine. (Your file 51-0-10, letter dated Jan 19-45) An older brother also caused similar trouble when in attendance. The Principal thought, and I concur, that disciplinary action should be taken in this case to act as a deterrent should any other similar plans be in the making and the girl was taken to the Good Shepherd Reformatory for a time. In the ordinary course of events she would have been discharged from the School this June.

I trust this action is approved.

H. C. Rice, Agent.

Albert Sewell or Albert Augustine, an Indian boy, whose mother is the wife of Lenny Sewell of the Bathurst Reserve, and who is at present not living with her husband, has been turning up in different parts of this agency and has been very hard to keep in one place. The boy has been neglected all through life and is consequently showing the results of same.

On February 10th., Dr. Myers of Moncton telephoned me that this boy was at his office, destitute, suffering from scabies. He had been living with an immigrant family at Salisbury for the last three weeks. The doctor told me that he had arranged with the police in Moncton to give him protection that night. I then called the police and asked them to keep him over Sunday.

On Monday morning I called Father Brown at Shubenacadie, and he agreed to take him in if I would receive your authority. I then went to Moncton and when I got there I found, through the Mounted Police, that the boy had stolen a number of articles from the family with whom he had been living. Those goods to a great part were still in his possession, and were turned over to Constable Bryenton of the Moncton detachment R.C.M.P. As it was getting well on into the afternoon when I was through with the Police, I started for Shubenacadie with the boy, stopping over night at Truro and delivering the boy to Shubenacadie School on Tuesday morning Feb. 13th.,

I am enclosing application for admission re this boy for your approval. You will note that it is signed only by myself, as the whereabouts of the father and mother are unknown at the present time.

In reference to this case, I am forwarding shortly,
a bill from the Moncton Police Department for 3 meals amounting to $1.20 and a bill from Mrs. Maclean of Salisbury for the amount of $20.00 for board for this boy while he was at her home.

I shall not forward these bills until I have authority covering same from your Department.

It was my pleasure, while at Shubenacadie, to inspect briefly the institution, and I feel that a great deal of good work is being accomplished there. I would like to see, at some later date, this the largest agency in N.B. being afforded an opportunity of having more of our destitute Indians admitted to this school, than we are now being allowed.

Indian Agent.
