(ASSISTANCE TO SHUBENACADIE DETACHMENT)

15-2-49.

On this date a telephone call was received from Father BROWN, Supt. of the Shubenacadie Indian School stating that the captionally noted girl, 15 years of age, had escaped from the school the previous evening. He gave a description of the girl and requested that some assistance be given by this detachment in locating her. This was immediately done, patrol being made to Pictou Landing Indian Reservation, as far as could be made by car, then on foot.

The complete reserve was covered this date by Cst. Drayton and the writer, but at none of the homes could any information be gained in regard to the girl, all stating that they knew her but that they had not seen her. She has two sisters living on the reservation, namely Mrs. John Henry RAPPEL and Mrs. Rod MCKENZIE. These women stated that if she should come to the reservation they would send her back, but this of course is very unlikely as the Indians here are not at all truthful.

Another sister of Hazel HOCKWOOD, Mrs. Martin FRANCIS lives just out of Trenton, N.S., and patrol was also made there but without result. A few Indian families who live in the "Pre Pub" district of New Glasgow were visited, and one man especially, Mr. WILSON who is considered to be fairly truthful stated that if he heard any word of her he would immediately call his office.

On this date patrol was again made to Pictou Landing and all of the places already mentioned above were again visited. No news of the girl was obtained however, so the families in Trenton and New Glasgow were visited a second time, but also without results. It is now thought that this girl did not come to this district or some word would undoubtedly have come to light. In view of this then, one copy of report is being forwarded direct to Shubenacadie Detachment, and unless otherwise instructed the file will be considered closed at this point.

CONCLUDED. HANDED OVER TO DETACHMENT CONCERNED.

Cst.

Further to C.R. of the 18th instant in connection with the above. This date, on receipt of information from the East Shubenacadie District to the effect that a young Indian girl was staying at the home of one Mrs. Calvin Nose, a neighbor, who could not advise us of her name but the description tallied closely with that of the above named. A check-up was immediately made with the result that the above named was located and returned to the Indian School and handed over to the Authorities in charge.

The residence of Mrs. Nose is about three miles from the Indian School, and Mrs Nose advises that this girl arrived at her house shortly after 10:00 P.M. of the 17-2-45. The girl asked for a drink of water and stated that she was on her way to Truro. Mrs. Nose asked her in for the night and that it would be far better to continue her trip in the morning. The following morning she learned from the girl that she had escaped from the School and was on her way to join her father in Maine, U.S.A. This girl being of a very timid disposition was persuaded to remain by Mrs Nose until found by the School Authorities or by the Police. However, Mrs Nose made no effort herself to notify the proper authorities of this Indian girls whereabouts after having knowledge of her escape.

After handing this girl over to the School Authorities, Fr. Brown was advised of the above and that Mrs Nose apparently harboured this girl or at least made no effort to advise of her whereabouts. Fr. Brown stated that he desires no further action be taken and expressed his appreciation of having this girl returned as it has a great morale effect on the students.

Indian Affairs Branch, Dep't of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Louis Lafforty Family, Fairvale Station, N.B.

Enclosed you will find copy of a letter which I sent to Rev. J.W. Brown, Principal of the Indian Residential School Shubenacadie, N.S., contents of which are self explanatory.

As you know, Louis Lafforty also his son, Francis Joseph are in the Saint John Tuberculosis hospital. Two of the boys, Harold and Henry were placed in the residential school this Fall. Susan (Mrs. Louis) Lafforty and three of her children, Mary Ann, age 9; Annie Elizabeth, age 5 and John Joseph, age 3, were living near Fairvale Station and receiving help monthly from the Indian Affairs Branch.

Complaints were received to the effect that Mrs. Lafforty was going to Saint John often and leaving the small children alone even sometimes all night. I investigated and found this to be true although a Mr. Noel J. Gould was there at the time. He was Mrs. Lafforty's father. I persuaded this man to stay with the family and get wood for them also cover the shack with tar paper and line it inside with sheathing paper. Mr. Gould had agreed to stay all winter and for this I was to give him one adult ration. This was on November 15th. On November 20th I received a call from the Saint John police stating that the C.N.R. police had picked up Mrs. Lafforty and handed her over to them but as she had started to hemorrhage she was placed in the Saint John Gen. hospital. They asked me about the children but I assured them that the children were not alone as I had been there the week previous and hired their grandfather to stay with them. They then told me that it would be some time before Mrs. Lafforty would be able to go home.

I went to Fairvale Station and talked to Mr. Gould who told me he would not manage there alone and asked me to let him go back to his home in Sydney, N.S., stating he was too old to do everything. I went to Bloomfield Station and Plumswell where some Indian families were living but none would take the children to board. I then returned to Hampton and phoned to Rev. F. Brown
Principal of the Shubenacadie Residential School and asked him if he would take the oldest girl. (See letter attached). I made arrangements for her transportation and then brought the two smaller children to Oromocto where I placed them in the home of Mrs. David Paul, an Indian woman who agreed to keep them for $5.00 a week plus a few clothes when needed. The $5.00 to be taken in groceries from F.F. McElroy's Store.

Mrs. Lafforty had a miscarriage according to the Police Matron, Saint John, N.B. She was also drunk. This woman had been reporting to the Health Centre weekly for treatment (Venereal)

I trust my action meets with your approval but under the circumstances there was nothing else I could do.

Dear Sir:

We herewith apply for approval of the dismissal of Michael Sylliboy, No. 220.

This boy is thirteen years old, has been in the school for four years, and has made no progress in school work at all. He is still in Grade 1.

Since he came, he has been subject to fits but this year, he has had them much more frequently; in fact he had three in the last month. We feel that for his own safety, as well as the safety of the other children, on stairs, etc., we should send him home to his mother.

We have discussed the matter with Mr. MacKinnon, the Indian Agent, for Cape Breton, who, in turn has discussed the matter with his mother, and it is perfectly agreeable to all concerned, that Michael remain home when he goes at the end of this school term.

Yours very truly,

REVEREND J.M. BROWN, Principal.

Dear Sirs:

I have been consulted by Benjamin J. Brooks of the Indian Reserve at Shubenacadie Nova Scotia, concerning the disposition of his two sons Norman Brooks, and Victor Albert Brooks, ten and nine years old respectively.

These boys are the sons of Mr. Brooks by his first marriage. His wife died about five years ago and for the past three years these boys have been in the Resident Indian School at Shubenacadie. A year ago Mr. Brooks says that Mr. Rice, the Indian Agent for that district, advised him that the boys after they had completed this year at school would not be required to return. He now understands that it is the intention to return these boys to the Resident Indian School at the end of the summer holidays.

Mr. Brooks having remarried and established a home on the reservation at Shubenacadie in which he has accommodation for these two boys is very anxious to keep them at home with him and allow them to attend the new school being completed on the Reserve.

I am advised that Mr. Brooks is a good provider and is a registered stevedore in Halifax. Also that there is no suggestion that these boys are in need of correction or detention. In view of the above it would seem reasonable that this man should be allowed to maintain these two children in his own home. Would you make inquiries about this matter and advise me if there is any reason why this can not be done.

Yours very truly,

Richard A. Donahoe
Ottawa, July 30th, 1945.

Edward Paul (Indian) Escaped
Day from the Shubenacadie Indian School, Shubenacadie, N.S. (Aust., to Indian Department).

At 7:30 P.M. this date, a telephone call was received from Father Brown, Supt. of the Shubenacadie Indian School, then at South Maidland, to the effect that the above named had escaped from the School at 7:30 this morning and had been observed in the woods in South Maidland about half an hour ago. Father Brown requested the services of the Police Dog in an effort to trail and intercept this youth.

A patrol was immediately made with Cst. Benson and P.D. "Chips" to South Maidland where Father Brown was met. At this point Mr. Thompson who had observed the Indian youth in the woods, was requested to take the Dog Section to the location where P.D. "Chips" was put to work on the trail by the Dog Master.

It was ascertained from Father Brown that this youth was 13 years of age and that his home is at Eskasoni, Cape Breton, N.S.

While the Police Dog was searching towards the south of South Maidland, a young lad named Carr reported to the Writer that the Indian youth being sought was observed by him about ten to fifteen minute ago at a point near the railway station. The search was immediately continued at this point, and along the railway tracks for some distance by the Dog Section. On their return, the patrol returned to the local general store where it was found that the Indian youth had in the meantime come out of the woods and given himself up.

The above named was conveyed to the Shubenacadie Indian School and handed over to Father Brown, Supt of the School.

Mileage: P.C. 5769 - 40 miles.

CONCLUDED - HANDED OVER.

Francis had run away from the Shubenacadia Indian school and had been picked up by a freight train crew, when he was found riding on one of the freight cars. He was picked up at 4:30 A.M. of the 24-9-45 and handed over to the Investigation Department upon arrival at Halifax.

Further to the above, and acknowledging receipt of copy of Windsor Detachment report dated 21-9-45 received direct, concerning the arrest of John MICHAELS (Indian).

On the morning of Sunday, 23-9-45, a call was received from the above School to the effect that Angus FRANCIS (Indian) had again escaped from the School. This lad is 10 years old. Further, that this lad had been traced as far as the river about 200 yards away where cast-off clothing belonging to the lad were picked up. The Writer immediately checked the railway station and highway in the immediate vicinity as the lad had less than an hour start. In the meantime Cst. H.R.Babson and P.D. "Chin" directed their activities to where footprints of this lad's were discernible along the sand bars of the river shore. The P.D. worked his way along over the railway embankment and towards the main highway of Route No. 2, where the trail and scent was lost. As the only logical way for this lad to have continued his trip was northward on the main highway or in the woods skirting the highway, the Dog Section continued along northward where practical while the Writer advised certain persons further along to be on the look-out for this Indian lad.

This A.M. Sgt. Rowley of Division Headquarters advised that one Angus FRANCIS (Indian) age 10 years was picked up in Halifax, and on learning that this lad was an escapee from the School at this point, arrangements were made to hold him pending escort by the Indian School. Fr. Brown, Bp., of the Indian School, made the trip to Halifax and returned with this Indian lad to the School.

Enquiries made since reveals that this Indian lad was picked up by a truck enroute to Truro, at a point near the highway river bridge at Shubenacadie and dropped off near the Mill Brook Reserve at Truro. The Train conductor advises the Station Master here that an Indian lad did get on the train at Truro when his back was turned and managed to continue the trip unaffected passed Shubenacadie, and from here on to Halifax, N.S.

Fr. Brown advises the Writer that as this lad has escaped from the School twice within a short time, and this School does not lock its doors, FRANCIS will be committed to St. Patrick's Home for Boys at Halifax, N.S., in the near future.

No Expenses Incurred.

The above-mentioned Indian child was brought to the Truro Reserve by the father and left with no arrangements made as to maintenance or care.

I am enclosing herewith Application for Admission to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School. You are requested to complete same and forward to Ottawa. Also notify the Regional Director of Family Allowances, Quebec, of this child's attendance at the Residential School, Shubenacadie.

J. E. Morris,
Welfare and Training.
SCHOOL - two-rooms. This is a good building with a bright basement kept in excellent condition. Sister Mary of the Holy Eucharist is in charge, and with the assistance of teaching Sisters the children are orderly and well behaved. As is usual, when visiting schools under their supervision, the children rendered songs. The attendance is good and the Sister reported that there are only two families not making their children attend regularly. She stated that the Family Allowance is certainly having a good effect in this respect.

Agent Arsenault was requested to interview the parents and advise them that their children must attend school regularly and on time. If not the Family Allowance cheques will be administered through the agent's office. All the children appeared to be in good health, well fed, and well dressed.

Two boys, eleven and twelve, sons of Joseph H. Isaac, have not been attending school. The father reported that his wife has been in the hospital for several years, and as he was unable to obtain the services of a housekeeper it was necessary to keep the boys at home to look after fires. He is receiving Family Allowances for these boys and they should be in school. There is little likelihood of Isaac getting a housekeeper; therefore, the two boys should be sent to the Shubenacadie Residential School.

ATTENTION - MR. PHILAN. Father Brown and Sister Superior of the Residential School have been consulted, and they stated that there is room for these two boys. It is recommended that Agent Arsenault be instructed to provide the children with transportation and advise the Family Allowance officials accordingly.
Ottawa, 5th November, 1945.

Mr. A.E. Arsenault, Indian Agent,
Restigouche, Quebec.

I believe it to be in their best interests to send them to the Shubenacadie Residential School and I enclose the usual forms which should be completed and returned to us.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sir:

Re: William COPE (Indian),
escaped from Shubenacadie Indian School.

1. I am in receipt of a report from our Antigonish detachment that the above named Indian boy, aged twelve, was located by our Antigonish detachment roaming the streets of Antigonish at a late hour on the 18th instant, and he admitted that he had escaped from the Indian School at Shubenacadie.

2. Information concerning this matter was reported to you by the N.C.O., in charge, Shubenacadie detachment, and advice was received that you could take charge of the boy at New Glasgow. COPE was therefore escorted to New Glasgow where arrangements had been made by you for his return to Shubenacadie.

3. In addition to COPE, another Indian youth, Harry SMITH, is reported to have been located at Mulgrave by members of the Military Provost Corps, and it is understood that this boy was placed on the train for Shubenacadie, his fare having been provided by you.

Rev. Father:

Referring to my telegram of March the 16th, regarding the case of Marian and Gertrude Beadle for their admission at your residential school, I wish to secure you some other information concerning the family.

Mrs. Beadle (Jennie) was an Indian woman of Pietou Landing, and she came on Restigouche Reserve last fall with her four children.

They were staying in a very poor house on the Reserve, and as Mrs. Beadle was working in the town of Campbellton for her living, the children were obliged to stay home alone and were not attending school.

When Mr. J.E. Morris, of the Welfare Division, Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa, has visited the families, he has realized the situation of the children, and it is why he asked me to take the necessary steps to have the children admitted at your school at once.

I enclose for your information, a declaration signed by the mother, Mrs. Jennie Beadle.

Hoping the poor children are now under your supervision and they will appreciate their living condition.

Charlottetown, P.E.I., March 22, 1946

Indian Affairs Branch
Department Of Mines & Resources
OTTAWA.

I am enclosing an Application For Admission form which has been filled out for Margaret Janett Francis. Mrs. Francis has already taken the girl to the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie. I sent these forms to Mrs. Francis telling her to take the child to Dr. Martin at Mt. Stewart and have her given a physical examination, and then return the forms to me so I could forward them to Ottawa. In the meantime I asked Father Brown if there was a place for her at the school; he assured me there would be a place when the application was approved by Ottawa. Mrs. Francis called at the office here on her way to N.S.; unfortunately I was out at the Hospital at the time and did not see her. Fr. Brown then returned the application to me. I am hoping what has been done will meet with approval.

J. E. Daly
Indian Agent
National Health & Welfare - Ottawa, Ont.

With reference to your letter of March 20th re Eskimo Children in the Children's Hospital, Halifax.

I have made arrangements with the Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, to have these children placed there as soon as quarantine for Measles are lifted on these children, and held at the school until advised by you that children are to be sent back north.

I also contacted the Children's Hospital by phone and have arranged with them to advise me as soon as these children can leave hospital, and will have them escorted to the Indian Residential School at that date.

H.C. Rice
Indian Agent.
Memorandum:

Mr. R.A. Gibson

Enclosed is a copy of a letter from Agent Rice concerning Eskimo children. We think it advisable to get them away from the hospital as soon as they are ready for discharge. Agent Rice does not state what rate for board will be charged but we will make the necessary arrangements. It will likely be the end of the month and the cost of board will, I presume, then be the responsibility of this Department.

W.L. Falconer, M.D.,
Actg. A/Supt., Indian Health Services.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
April 11th, 1946.

Indian Affairs Branch - Ottawa, Ont.

I am forwarding you six applications for admission to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, forms complete for six Howe children.

These children I had to take and put in the Residential School as it was a very deserving case. One form you will note is signed by Mrs Bridget Howe, this is one of her illegitimate children, the rest are supposed to belong to him.

The husband has been overseas for the past three years but arrived back about two months ago. While he was overseas his wife was behaving in a very bad manner, drinking and consorting with other men. She also had one child while he was away by another man. I considered the living conditions very bad and had warned her several times that I would take her children from her.

If this hadn't been such a problem of finding places for nine children they would have been taken from her long ago.

When he returned I thought conditions would improve but apparently they continued in the same line so I decided to take these six and put them in the Residential School for awhile until conditions improved, if they do.

Trust this is satisfactory to you.

H.C. Rice
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, April 15th, 1946.

Quarter Report for the months of January, February and March

Constable:

The Constable is doing a good job on the reserve, and there is less beer, drunkenness, etc. He seems to be watching this very sharp, and there is also very few fights. He is also giving a sharp check on school attendance. I had to take six children of Mrs. Ernest Howe and put them in the Indian Residential School. This woman has not been behaving herself for some time; she had one illegitimate child while her husband was overseas. I thought on his return that conditions would improve but if anything they were worse. Checking over the house, etc., I decided it was no place for the children so I had to have arrangements for them to stay at the school.

H. G. Rice
Indian Agent.
Quarter Report for the months of January, February and March

Eskimo's

The three eskimo children in the Children's Hospital, Halifax, at the present time are being held there on account of measles. I expect to have them removed in about two weeks and placed in the Indian Residential School until time for the sailing of the steamer to take them to their homes, which I understand will be some time in July.

H. C. Rice
Indian Agent.

Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia

Dear Sir:-

We beg to inform you that the following are eligible for discharge at the end of this school year:-

209 ... Joseph Michael, Eskasoni, C.B.
127 ... Stephen Morris, Shubenacadie Reserve
250 ... Noel Simon, Newcastle, N.B.

0193 ... Clara Bernard, Newcastle, N.B.
0200 ... Laura Jacobs
0205 ... Myrtle Sacobia.

Re: 0193. We obtained permission from the Department last year to hold this girl over for another year, owing to her home conditions. We have advised the Agent, and have been advised by him to send this girl to Newcastle for the present, and he will place her.

Re: 0200. Laura Jacobs came here from P.E.I. originally. Her father, Peter Jacobs, or Jacob Boucher, has been travelling around N.B. and N.S. He is no fit parent for this girl. We sent an older girl home a couple of years ago, had her placed, but she finally wound up with the father. The girl in question, Laura, is physically strong and robust, but mentally very weak. We feel that this girl should have some protection, and have made known the circumstances to Mr. Rice.

We do not feel that we should keep her here at this school any longer. We shall abide by the Agent's directions in this matter. We understand that he has taken it up with you.

We have advised the Agents concerning the dismissal of the others.

Yours very truly,

REVEREND J.M. Rice, Principal.

Philip Phelan,

J.D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

On the Woodstock reserve a few of the children are near sighted, two especially so, William Polches and Helen Polches, and both need spectacles.

The sewing and knitting lessons given the girls on the different reservations are very much liked by them, and excellent progress is being made especially among the older girls.

Lessons on personal cleanliness have also been given by the teachers from time to time, with excellent results.

While, however, the girls are being taught the uses of the sewing and knitting needles - the boys unfortunately have no means of improvement at their disposal - and therefore it is that I am of the opinion that if a central Industrial school were built where the boys could be taught useful trades, carpentering, blacksmithry, tailoring, etc., in addition to farming that much good might result.

It seems to me that the Tobique reservation would offer a splendid location for such a school, as there is both land and wood available in large measure there.

One thing badly needed in the Province is a furniture factory, and it seems to me that if in connection with an Industrial School there was a wood working factory, the native genius of the Indian might be turned to good account, for there is no doubt that in the matter of carving he easily excels, and there would be a good market for his carved work.

From the Agent at Tobique Point, I learned that he was successful in cultivating a taste for vegetable gardening among some of the younger men of that reserve, and that he had great hopes for the incoming year in that branch of industry. In regard to getting them, however, to keep to their own particular line of
work, he was not so successful, as the feeling spread among them that he was trying to keep them down instead of advancing them in life. Were a Central School (Industrial) established here however, where the young men could go after grading from the new schools, I feel this idea would disappear, and the Indian boy retain the practical use of the few tools he knows how to work so well with now, and acquiring the use of others which would fit him for the battle of life and make him a useful citizen of whatever place he afterwards resided in.

I am, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Jno. J. Ryan,
Supt. Indian Schools.

Your obedient servant,

May I suggest to the Department the advisability of establishing a boarding and industrial school at a central point in Nova Scotia for the benefit of Indian children in this province? It would not be a matter of experiment in view of the Department's experience with such schools in other parts of Canada. I understand that institutions of that kind have been highly successful not only in teaching the three "R's", but also in providing young Indians with a technical education that enables them when they go out in the world, to become self-sustaining and useful citizens of their country. What has been done in other parts of this Dominion should be susceptible of accomplishment also in Nova Scotia.

A. J. Boyd,
Indian Superintendent

May 19, 1924.
Sir:

I beg to submit my report on farming operations among the Indians of Nova Scotia during the season of 1924.

However, notwithstanding the discouraging results of last year's operations, I regard farming as the particular occupation most likely to bring a reasonable measure of prosperity to our Indians in the end, but under changed conditions. They must be taught to farm intelligently. I am quite persuaded that the spasmodic efforts, made from time to time, with that object in view, have been of very little, if any, practical benefit. Such education to be effective should begin at an early age and be continued for a certain necessary period. Therefore, I would advise the establishment of an industrial school, centrally located, to accommodate the Indian girls and boys of the three Maritime Provinces, where they would receive a common school education and vocational training to fit them for useful citizenship. The initial expense connected with such an institution would no doubt be considerable, but I believe it would be amply justified by results.

Your obedient servant,

(Sgd.) A. J. Boyd.

OTTAWA,
May 28/25.
During my visit in August last to the various schools and reserves in the Maritime Provinces, I was impressed with the need of the establishment of a Residential School for the education and care of the orphans and neglected children from the various reserves.

At the present time we have no institution in which to place such cases. There are some thirty-five children in institutions in Halifax for whom we are paying a grant for maintenance and tuition at the rate of $260.00 per capita per annum. Besides, we have several children in institutions in St. John and elsewhere in the Province of New Brunswick. We have three children in institutions in Prince Edward Island. There are quite a number of children for whom it was necessary to obtain homes with the Indians for which we pay them an allowance. Besides, there are in towns and villages Indian children who do not attend any school.

I am of the opinion that a Residential School should be built at a central point convenient to the railways and of a size sufficient to accommodate eighty children. This matter was brought to my attention by several of our agents and Father Ryan, Inspector of Indian Schools for the Province of New Brunswick. They all emphasized the need of an institution of this kind being established at an early date.

I think this question should receive consideration.

Industrial School.

"I feel that we are now up against a great problem for the most of our reserves, in not having an industrial school to care for about 50 of our school children (or more) who are not attending school. It is that the Dept. has provided schools, teachers and books, but to them the next step is to get some to attend school. Parents take their children away with them to different places, while others will not send their children at all to school. Why? They say the children do not like to go. It seems a pity, for in many cases, it is the brightest children who remain away from school, and that, at the early age of 12 or 13.

What is the result? Their children exercise a very bad influence on those going to school. I think the Government can readily understand what their children are doing about the reserve and all say long in idleness. Now, can we proceed under such relaxation in bringing about better conditions among our Indians? There are many orphans cast into the hands of other Indian families to care for - for which the Dept. pays certain sums of money. Very often this money only promotes idleness among such Indian families while the poor little orphans get little or nothing.

I should think the Maritime Provinces should have such a school at once. In fact, the absence of this Industrial School has, in the past 20 years, proven a grave financial drainage to the Dept. and more than that, new avenues of alarming financial waste have been opened up to no good purpose. That can only be closed by such an Industrial home. Could the Government be made see this, I feel that in less than twenty years from the time this home was built, that such a financial leakage would be checked as to almost pay for such a home, besides the Indian question in the Maritime Provinces would then, and only then, be solved for all time.

Every day we remain without this Industrial School, we are going back, and education is costing more with but little results."

(Signed) F. C. Ryan
Inspector of Indian Schools for N. B.

April 23, 1927.

Dear Mr. Boyd:

Pursuant to our conversation, I have to inform you that it is my intention to arrange for the early erection of an Indian residential school in Nova Scotia. As you are well aware, there are many Indian children, for whom a suitable home must be provided if they are to receive an education. We already have a large number of children in institutions in Halifax and elsewhere and there are others for whom we are paying board while they reside in foster homes on the reserve.

I believe that an institution to accommodate 125 children is required. There should be a suitable farm with plenty of pasture land. In addition to the main building there will be required a barn, hen house, implement shed, cold storage and other outbuildings. The children would receive academic training, as well as instruction in farming, gardening, care of stock, carpentry in the case of the boys and for the girls, domestic activity.

Such an institution would require a reverend principal, an assistant, a farm instructor, an engineer-carpenter and perhaps one labourer. The domestic and classroom activities should be in the hands of from eight to ten Sisters, who would, of course, be under the general supervision of the Rev. Principal.

The Department is prepared to undertake the capital expenditure necessary for such an institution and its equipment as soon as Parliament provides the necessary funds. There is an appropriation to commence the activity this fiscal year and I am hopeful that arrangements can be made for a suitable site and for some building activity this summer.

It is the practice, with institutions of this kind, to meet the major portion of the current expenses by a per capita grant - so much per child per annum, based upon the actual attendance. In the case of this school, I believe a grant of $150 should be allowed.

Attached you will find a set of plans for a Roman Catholic Indian residential school lately erected by this Department, and you may show these to any interested parties, so that they will have a general idea as to the type of main building the Department erects for this purpose.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Memorandum:

DR. SCOTT,

On Tuesday, the 19th instant, we arrived at Shubenacadie, N.S., to examine properties there for the proposed Indian residential school. J. L. Ilsley, LL.B., of Kentville, M.P. for Hants-Kings, met us there and assisted until a final selection was made. At that point, we had a preliminary look at the various sites that had been brought to our attention by letter and, without much hesitation, some confirmed our interest to the Etter and Gay Farms, which were carefully examined. Certain local persons with some influence were desirous that the Davis property be included in the final examination, but Mr. Ilsley and ourselves could not agree that it was suitable enough to be worthy of comparison with the other two.

It was considered advisable to proceed to Halifax for the 20th and 21st, for the purpose of meeting the church authorities and to look into building materials and sources of supply. The final selection of a site was postponed until Friday, the 22nd. On that date the Etter and Gay Farms were examined with considerable care. While the first named property appeared to possess more possibilities as a productive farm - a much wider choice of acreage being available for purchase - from every other angle the Gay property was more suitable.

The Gay property is situated one-half mile from the station at Shubenacadie - immediately on the outskirts of the village. The site is reached by good roads leading directly from the village. A distinct advantage over the other properties is that it is not necessary to cross the railroad when travelling to and from Shubenacadie. When it is pointed out that this railroad is the main line of the C.N.R., over which there is heavy traffic, the importance of this to the staff and children will be understood. The farm consists of approximately 65 acres of cultivated upland, 50 acres of woodland - 10 of which have already been cleared sufficiently for pasture and 5 acres of marshland, which produces hay perennially without attention. The property as a whole appears to be clean and well cultivated. We consider this Gay farm, which consists of 130 acres, more or less, large enough for the needs of the proposed institution for some time to come. The land appears to be clean and productive and is in one block. It should be mentioned that a fresh water lake, suitable for bathing, boating and fishing, just touches the northern boundary of the Gay farm.

On this property is an ideal building site. It commands a view of the countryside in all directions and the building will be seen from the railroad and from all of the

However, this feature was not worthy of serious thought as all materials would have to be unloaded from the cars into a vehicle and hauled up a difficult grade to the building. The Gay property without railroad to cross and only a short hundred yards farther from a railroad station had the distinct advantage of being near a post office and business community. We were warned by certain interested parties that the road leading to the Gay property, which happens to be the main road to Maitland, was flooded at certain seasons of the year. We made several inquiries from independent sources in this connection and we learned that the road was flooded for an hour or two a day in the spring of certain years only, but that it was not impassable even when flooded.

Mr. S. J. Etter wanted $13,500 for his farm, which consists of 270 acres. A lot of the value of this property is tied up in the buildings, the most important of which would have to be removed in the event of an Indian residential school being erected there. Mr. George Gay in his written offer to Mr. Indian Agent Taylor, asked $9,000 for his 130 acres, but we were able to secure from him an option on the property at $7,000, provided he be allowed to harvest this year's crop. He promised to do the fall ploughing and otherwise prepare the fields for next year's farming operations.

We wish to recommend that the farm of George Gay be surveyed at an early date, with a view to determining not only the exact size of the property but also the best building site. If everything is found as has been represented to us and the title is satisfactory, we believe it advisable to arrange the purchase. In our opinion it is easily the best property near Shubenacadie for an Indian residential school. When title is being searched, it should be ascertained what privileges the owners have in connection with the lake that touches the property and if there is a right of way around its southern extremity.

Some time ago, approximately one-eighth of an acre of this farm was sold for the site of a residence. Three
or four years ago, the purchaser, Mr. Allan S. Bitter, erected a residence, which would make a very suitable house for the farm instructor and other male members of the staff of the proposed school. This residence and lot, which is situate on the entrance road to the property can be purchased for $4,000, which sum is less than would be required to erect a suitable farmer's residence. We strongly recommend that this property, also, be purchased.

Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Mr. Lisley:

I have your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the purpose of the new Indian residential School at Shuswap Lake, B.C. You may be interested in a very brief review of Indian education in Canada, which will suggest the Department's general programme and will indicate the purposes and aims of the boarding school for Indian children in the East.

Prior to Confederation, Indian schools were supported, for the most part, by missionary societies, religious orders and the Indian bands themselves, little financial assistance being given by the legislatures. Low salaries were paid and the attendance was irregular and, as a consequence, the schools were not very effective. The British North America Act placed the responsibility for the Indians of Canada with the Federal Government, and this Department began to support existing schools and to establish others. By 1885, in eastern Canada, where the Indian was no longer living largely by the chase, day schools were conducted on reserves wherever it was possible to secure a worthwhile attendance. The Roman Catholic, Church of England, Methodist and Presbyterian Missionary Societies and Societies were associated with the Department in the conduct of most of these schools. The major portion of the expense was borne by Parliamentary Appropriation.

The problem of educating the children of the nomadic Indian groups of northwestern Ontario and of western Canada, generally, was largely unsolved, and the missionary societies and orders interested continued the establishment of boarding schools to supplement the day schools on the reserves. The advantages are rather keen on institutional activity, which has the advantage of placing child under Christian influence and supervision for 24 hours of the day. The Department of Indian Affairs soon recognized the socio-economic advantage of the residential school. Ordered habits, domestic arts for girls, farming, gardening, care of live stock, carpentry and other trades for boys were of much interest to the State. The Department supported these residential schools and established others, placing emphasis on vocational as well as academic training, and today they

To return to the problem in eastern Canada, where the day school has, and will have, the more important part, there remains the provision for orphans, illegitimates and neglected children. Further, many Indian children live too distant from Indian or public day schools to attend regularly. To care for all these under-privileged children, the residential school has been found the most satisfactory solution. There are 6 such schools in the vicinity of the Great Lakes.

It is for the under-privileged Indian child of Nova Scotia and the other Maritime Provinces that the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie is being established.

The Department conducts 22 Indian day schools on the reserves in the Maritimes - 11 in Nova Scotia, 10 in New Brunswick and one on Prince Edward Island. These institutions solve the ordinary problems. There remain the under-privileged children. Over 50 of the most urgent cases are in convents and orphanages in Halifax and other centres. There are now 30 additional children needing maintenance as well as education. These will form the nucleus for the pupilage of the Shubenacadie School. Accommodation for 125 is being provided. The 45 children required to fill the school will be recruited from among those who are of or with families in a semi-institute condition. The cost of maintaining pupils in their own schools will be less than the fees paid to private institutions. Further, at Shubenacadie, the physical equipment and the courses of instruction are especially designed to meet the particular needs of our wards.

The educational activity at Shubenacadie will be academic and vocational. Classroom work will be comparable to that in the public schools of Nova Scotia and will be inspected, at request, by officers of the Provincial Department of Education. Girls will be trained in the domestic arts; and boys, in farming, gardening and the care of stock. Later, it may be possible to give a thorough course in manual training. It is the object and desire of the Department that graduates of this school will become self-supporting and will not return to their old environment.

Practically 100% of the Indians in the Maritimes are Roman Catholic and the Department has secured the services of the Reverend Father Mackey for principal and the Sisters of Charity for the inside staff.
staff. These church workers will be responsible for the school activity, generally, and will see that the pupils receive a training in religious education.

At these residential schools, the Department provides the buildings, farm and stock and whatever furnishings and equipment are necessary at the outset for their satisfactory conduct. There is also given a per capita grant, based on the average attendance. This grant and the farm or other school earnings care for all current expenses except classroom equipment, medical services and drugs, and are used for replacing worn out equipment. Major repairs to buildings and mechanical plant are made by the Department and are not a charge on school grant or other earnings. The management is expected to look after minor repairs and to keep all property in good condition.

It is necessary for me to be in British Columbia this month and I leave Ottawa on Tuesday morning. Some time in April, I shall be glad to enlarge on this subject whenever an interview is convenient. In the meantime, I have instructed Mr. Perrier to make an appointment with you to discuss any phase of the activity in which you are especially interested.

The Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, which will be opened in the near future, has been erected by the Department of Indian Affairs for the academic instruction and vocational training of those Indian children in the Maritimes whose needs are not being satisfied by the day schools which are conducted on the Indian reserves. Accommodation has been provided for 125 children and the necessary staff of instructors.

The Department of Indian Affairs conducts 22 day schools on the Indian reserves of the Maritimes - 11 in Nova Scotia, 10 in New Brunswick and one on Prince Edward Island. These schools solve the ordinary problem. There remains the necessity of providing for orphans, neglected children and those who live too distant from day schools to attend regularly. It is for these underprivileged children that the residential school has been erected at Shubenacadie. There are 6 such institutions in the vicinity of the Great Lakes in Ontario and many in Western Canada, but the one lately constructed in Nova Scotia is the first residential school for Indian children in the East. For some time it has been known at Ottawa that a school of this kind was needed in the Maritimes. The present Superintendent General of the Department, the Honourable Charles Stewart, satisfied that the time had come when something should be done, secured an appropriation from Parliament. In a few months, the school will be equipped and ready for the reception of pupils.

Following the well-established policy, this school will be conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, as the Indians for whom it is to provide education are all adherents of that faith. From the establishment of the first industrial school, nearly one hundred years ago, there has been cooperation between the Government and the various denominations interested in missionary work among the Indians. The benefit arising from this system is that the Department obtains the zealous assistance of those interested in the evangelization of the Indians, and the general education and civilization go hand in hand with Christianization. Very marked success has followed the association of these two forces working towards one and the same end.

Rev. Father J. P. Mackey has been appointed principal and under the Department's direction he will have general charge of the school. The Sisters of Charity will conduct the domestic and classroom activities; teachers and all other instructors will be fully qualified for their respective duties. The managers of the school will be expected to conduct the institution upon the revenue derived from a per capita grant without further assistance from Parliamentary Appropriation. It is found that this method insures economical management.

Only Indian children, wards of the Dominion Government, are eligible for admission, and, before being placed on the roll,
will undergo a careful physical examination by a competent physician.

The educational activity at Shubenacadie will be academic and vocational. The classroom work will be comparable to that in the public schools of Nova Scotia and will be inspected, at the Department's request, by officers of the Provincial Department of Education. Girls will be trained in the domestic arts; and boys, in farming, gardening and the care of stock. Later, it may be possible to give a thorough course in manual training. The physical equipment and the courses of instruction are especially designed to meet the particular needs of Indian children. It is the object and desire of the Department that graduates of this school will become self-supporting and will not return to their old environment and habits.

The Dominion Government has provided the farm and main building. This building will house the pupils and instructors and provides all the accommodation necessary for classroom and domestic instruction. In due course, there will be erected barns, workshops and the other outbuildings that are necessary for this type of school. Furnishings, equipment and live stock will be purchased in the near future. The capital expenditure was provided in the appropriation for Indian education and there will be a yearly grant for current expenses.

RAPHAEL'S METHODS OF EARLY DAYS

Prior to Confederation there was practically no organization of Indian schools in Canada. The Roman Catholic Missionaries interested in this work were scattered throughout the country wherever and whenever the activity gave promise of success. The Anglican Church of England chaplain to the Hudson's Bay Company opened the first school for Indian children on the Red River in 1820. In 1834 Father Laval, a French priest tried an agricultural school at St. Boniface near Fort St. Paul, now St. Boniface, Man., in 1834. There were also missionary schools in various parts of the West, all conducted by Roman Catholic, Anglican, Presbyterian and Methodist missionaries. In British Columbia the Anglican Church of England chaplain to the Hudson's Bay Company began work early in the 19th century, and founded what is now the present Lytton Indian Residential School.

At the time of Confederation the Indians were taught in small schools with small salaries, and attendance was irregular, thus making the schools ineffective.

During the year ended March 31st, 1927 there were 16 residential schools and 200 day schools in operation in Canada, attended by 1,470 pupils. In addition the Department of Indian Affairs has approved the opening of 15 combined white and Indian schools. The total number of pupils attending these schools during the year was 14,710, and the average attendance per school was 986. These schools were actively engaged in the maintenance of the regular day schools. This co-operation of the churches has resulted in the establishment of several new schools such as the one now established at Shubenacadie, N.S., as follows: Roman Catholic, 42; Church of England, 39; United Church, 13; Presbyterian, 2.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING AT THE SCHOOLS

In addition to the regular academic work at all Indian schools, there is vocational training at all the residential schools. At the new institution at Shubenacadie there will be farming, carpentry, blacksmithing, stock, manual training and domestic instruction. The Vocational Division of the Department of Indian Affairs assists the schools in preparing students to start farming and housekeeping. At the present time, in all other Indian residential schools, the provincial Departments of Education have fully qualified teachers will be engaged. Arrangements have been made with the Provincial Department of Education for the appointment of inspectors and separate school inspectors for supervision of the vocational instruction, and Department officers will constantly supervise the vocational training.

All developments in the new structure along educational lines will be made under the best possible facilities for the education of the underprivileged Indian will be provided.

The expenditure for Indian education was approximately $1,000,000 appropriation for the fiscal year ended March 31st, 1927, of which $24,125.61 was spent in Nova Scotia, $1,000,000 in Ontario, $1,000,000 in Quebec, and $1,000,000 in Prince Edward Island.

Modern School Is Established At Shubenacadie For Children Of Maritime Province Indians

REV. J. P. MACKEY IS SCHOOL PRINCIPAL

Church And State Co-operate To Teach And Care For The Young Micmac

By RUSSELL G. EHRHART

With the opening of the new school building at Shubenacadie, the religious and educational life of the Micmac Indians of Nova Scotia has been greatly improved. The new school, located near the town of Shubenacadie, will provide a modern facility for the education of the Micmac children of the region.

The school was constructed by the Government of Nova Scotia, and is being operated by the Department of Indian Affairs. The school will be staffed by both Micmac and non-Micmac teachers, ensuring a balanced approach to education.

The new school building is situated on a large plot of land, providing ample space for outdoor activities and sports. The building itself is a modern structure, featuring large windows and a spacious interior. It is equipped with all necessary facilities for teaching and learning.

The school will provide an education that is tailored to the needs of the Micmac children. The curriculum will include both traditional Micmac teachings and modern academic subjects. The school will also offer vocational training, preparing the children for future employment.

The school will be administered by competent staff, ensuring high standards of education and care. The school will provide a safe and supportive environment for the children, allowing them to grow and develop in a positive manner.

The opening of the new school is a significant step forward in the education of the Micmac children. It represents a commitment to improving the lives of these children and their families. The school will provide a foundation for a brighter future for the Micmac people of Nova Scotia.

EDUCATING OUR INDIANS IS AN IMPORTANT TASK

NEW SCHOOL IN THE MARITIMES

Dept. of Indian Affairs Conducts Day and Residential Schools Throughout Canada

One of the very important functions of the Department of Indian Affairs is the providing of educational facilities for Indian children throughout the Dominion. Day schools are conducted on reserves in every province and where conditions permit residential schools are also operated. In order to provide academic instruction and vocational training for those living on the Maritime reserves whose needs are not met by the twenty-two day schools conducted in that part of the country, a new residential school has been erected at Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia. There are six such institutions in Ontario, three in the Great Lakes in Ontario and many in Western Canada but the one lately erected is the first in the Maritimes.

The new school, which will house 125 pupils and the necessary teaching staff, will be opened about the middle of September. Classroom and domestic instruction will be opened about the middle of September, together with the barns, workshops, and other equipment necessary for the vocational courses.

According to reports received by the Department of Indian Affairs in the Maritime Provinces, eleven are located in New Brunswick, five in Nova Scotia, two in New Brunswick, and one on Prince Edward Island. These schools solve the ordinary problems of the Indian children residing in close proximity to the schools. There remains the necessity of providing for orphans, widows' children, and those who live too far from the day schools to be regular attendants. It is for these underprivileged children that the residential school has been established.

From the establishment of the first industrial school nearly one hundred years ago, there has been cooperation between the Dominion Government and the various religious bodies interested in missionary work among the Indians. In following this well established policy the new residential school will be conducted under the auspices of the Roman Catholic Church, as the Indian bands in the Maritimes are all adherents of that faith.

Rev. Father J. P. MacKey has been appointed principal and has been called in from Quebec. Under the Department's direction he will have general charge of the institution. The Sisters of Charity, who will conduct the domestic and classroom activities, will move into their quarters about the middle of August.

It is anticipated that the teachers will be fully qualified, and the educational activities will be academic and vocational. The vocational work will be comparable to that in the public schools of the province. At the Department's request the school will be affiliated with the Provincial Department of Education. The vocational training will include carpentry, blacksmithing, sewing, etc., for the boys, farming, gardening, care of stock, and possibly manual training. It is planned that children from the school in a position to become self-supporting and independent.

INDIAN WRITES ABOUT BUILDING OF COLLEGE

Truro, N.S. — Claiming that "fishing, trapping, hunting and making" are the natural trades of his people, an aboriginal man in Truro, Nova Scotia, using under the nom de plume "Ghoosecap," expressed his views in the Letter column of the January 26 issue of the Truro News on the proposed Indian College to be built at Shubenacadie, N.S.

"Not very long ago," the letter states, "we Indians thought of our some thousand dollars Indian College fund as something like the final touches of our long drawn out civilization is to be given, where everything was to be obliterated or cast into the Bottomless Pit. But now, however, at least at this time, some smart young Indians can become Priests, Doctors, and teachers, secretaries and sales ladies just like the whites."

"Remembering my own experience of the fleecing or the kindness of White Men's education upon an Indian and knowing how unchangeable is the nature of the savage, I utter one of my great-great grand Father's grants and pray God will send Father Ghoosecap to come and save us which I hope he will do, for to be an Indian is to be nothing more than a loafer on, longing to see the wonders of this world which he sees but never can get. He is nearly forty years old. The Indians have been introduced in all our Reservations in Nova Scotia. Millions of dollars have been spent to educate 'The Indian.' Today we have a few educated Injin who eat his bread and butter through or by the use of his pen. After about two or three months after an Indian Priest is ordained and Indians' Doctor is graduated, the latter graduate will find the three working together at baskets and chopsticks. We must try to improve the condition of Micmac Indians in Nova Scotia by associating with them and everything else 'Indian.'

"Our last Christmas in the reserve here was a little different. Go to church in the morning, go back to your own house and go to bed. You see any Indian done it sixty years ago no prayers could have saved his soul. For our ancestors old Indian Christmas was all 'Indian,' all sane, while now they are being civilized from the Holy of Holies where flesh upon flesh is eaten day before Christmas until New Year. A New Year was always a reconciliation and a new beginning. So our modern Indian Christmas here was a mere shadow of our former ones."

Referring to your memorandum of the 26th ultimo, with attached correspondence from Colonel Cantley, R.F., to the Honourable the Minister, regarding the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, I have to say that this school was established for the benefit of the Indian children who are unable to attend our day schools. It is primarily for the purpose of educating orphan and neglected children, or children whose parents are unable to properly provide for them or those who are unable to attend our Indian day schools.

Each case is brought to our attention by the local Indian agent, who forwards an application on the form for that purpose. These children are kept in the school until they reach the age of 16 years. The case of each child is dealt with on its merits.

The school age and the authority under which children are placed in a residential school are set forth in Section 10 of the Indian Act.

In cases where the parents neglect to send their children to school, the Department can have them committed, under the Section of the Indian Act referred to above. It is only in exceptional cases, however, that this action is necessary. It is stated on the application for admission in each case that the child will remain in the school, under the guardianship of the Principal, for such term as the Department of Indian Affairs may deem proper.

With reference to communication received from Colonel Cantley, regarding the two Indians, Michael Paul and Peter Wilmot, who desire to have their daughters home for a holiday. I have to say that, as our funds for transportation of pupils for holidays have been so greatly reduced, the question of allowing holidays this year was left in the hands of the Principal, with the request that he would make the arrangements considered by him to be in the best interests of all concerned, and the parents to provide the cost of the transportation in going to the school and returning to the school, permission is granted for the children to go home on holiday. As the two Indians above referred to were unable to provide the cost of the transportation, the Principal kept their children at the school. Michael Paul has one daughter, Louise, 14 years of age, at the school, and Peter Wilmot has two daughters, Kate, aged 12, and Annie, aged 16.

Dear Mr. Cantley:

In reply to your letter of July 12th I wish to thank you for your kindly interest in the two Indians mentioned, Michael Paul and Peter Wilmot.

Monday, June 12th, I interviewed the Reverend J. Mackay, Superintendent of the Indian Residential School at Shubenacadie, and was informed by him that no children from this agency would be granted vacation this summer. When the parents of these children commit their charges to that institution they sign over the care of the children to the Superintendent, who has authority to judge how long the children must be kept there, and under what conditions they may be granted vacations.

During my short term of office I have not made any promises that houses would be built for any Indians, for the good reason that it is not within my power to make such promises. Last autumn I made several recommendations to the Department of Indian Affairs, and was plainly told that the Department had no funds with which to build houses. At that time this agency was granted some fifty-one dollars for very necessary building repairs, and in the month of January of this year a further fifty-one dollars was authorized to build a shack for an Indian whose children were suffering from exposure to the elements.

Perhaps you can sympathize with the unenviable position of an Indian Agent. There are really a number of Indians for whom houses should be built, and many others whose homes need repairs; but always I am informed that the Department has no funds for exceptional expenditures, and that expenses must be kept down. Added to all this, I am given the disconcerting notice that these poor wards of the Government...
must apply only through their agent, and that they are to be given notice to that effect. Only a couple of weeks ago I was given the discouraging notice that my expenditure for relief in this agency is entirely too high, and that I must reduce the amount, telling the Indians to be self-reliant and attempt to support themselves and their families by agriculture, fishing and other work. I feel for these poor creatures, believing that the present time of depression has made their lot a particularly hard one, since it is impossible for them to get remunerative work or to sell their handiwork, and so I believe that the Government should give them extraordinary aid in these extraordinary times, but what can I do?

I am,

September 6, 1933.

Memorandum:

MR. BUSKARD,

I have your memorandum of the 5th instant, with reference to correspondence received from Colonel Thomas Cantley, R. P., regarding holidays for the daughters of two Indians, Michael Paul and Peter Wilmot, who are attending the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

Memorandum of the 4th ultimo, signed by Mr. Williams, advised you why these children had not been allowed home for holidays. I note from your recent memorandum that the parents are now prepared to pay their transportation.

Classes have now been resumed at the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, and I consider it inadvisable to allow these children to go home. Besides, it is doubtful if the parents are able to properly care for them, and, in view of the approach of colder weather, it is quite possible that they would have to be returned to the school at departmental expense. I consider Colonel Cantley should be informed that the Department is not prepared to authorize these children being granted holidays at the present time.

Deputy Superintendent General.
We had to make an apology to Miss MacDonald, daughter of my friend, the Agent. When the young boys were out for a walk, and, as usual, two Sisters at the end of the line, two of MacDonald's daughters passed, and, while passing, threw the remark - "You would think that they would be trained better than that".

The Sisters knew it was for them, and wondered why, so, after enquiries, we found out, as the young ladies were passing - one is deformed - a "hunchback" - two of the boys said something to them.

After finding this out, I sent a note of apology to the young lady and the two boys to apologize in person. Mr. Agent MacDonald told them that if they made any more remarks, he would attend to them, so look out for more trouble.

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

With reference to your memorandum of the 11th instant, the following statement gives the status of the employees of the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School:

Principal: Rev. J. F. Mackey. He was appointed when the school was opened in 1929, at a salary of $75.00 a month.

Staff of School: Ten (10) Reverend Sisters, each of whom is paid $300.00 a year.

Farmer: Stewart Cooper - appointed in January, 1929, at a salary of $70.00 a month.

Assistant Farmer: L. Parker - appointed in April, 1930, at a salary of $60.00 a month.

Carpenter-Engineer: Ed. MacLeod - appointed in February, 1929, at a salary of $70.00 a month.

As the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School is conducted under Roman Catholic auspices, His Excellency the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Halifax was requested to nominate the Principal and the Reverend Sisters.

Information on file indicates that Messrs. Cooper, Parker and MacLeod were appointed with the concurrence of Hon. J. L. Ilsley, M. P.

This school is allowed a per capita grant for each Indian child in attendance and salaries and all other current expenses are paid by the Principal from the amount received from this source of revenue.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL

Re my visit to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

I wish to report that, during my inspection of Nova Scotia, I spent a whole afternoon at the above institution. This is a fine institution, built, I believe, on practically the same plan as the St. Mary's Indian Residential School (Blood R.C.), on the Blood Reserve.

There is a farm connected with the school and the staff was busy preparing the land for seeding. They have a fine herd of Ayrshire cows - all T.B. tested - and, therefore, the children are given all the milk they can drink.

I went over the school building from top to bottom and found everything in good order and the furnishings well taken care of. I noticed, however, that in several rooms the rain had beaten through the walls and the paint and kalsomine had become discoloured. The Principal has been in communication with the Department regarding this matter.

The heating plant, machinery, etc., were all in good order.

In the Principal, Rev. J. P. Mackey, the Department has, I believe, a good official. I also talked with the Sisters and other members of the staff and my opinion is that there is a very efficient staff at this school.
The girls are instructed in domestic science and the boys receive a certain amount of manual training.

There is, however, one thing that I wish to bring to the attention of the Department and that is the future of the pupils who are attending this school. The Department is well aware of the conditions that exist among the Indians in Nova Scotia and, unless a change is brought about, the young men and women graduating from this school from year to year will return to their people and in a short time will be asking for relief.

You will see from my general report that the Indians all over Nova Scotia are depending, for a livelihood, on what relief they get from the Department and the sale of Indian handicraft, such as baskets, axe and pick handles, and other articles too numerous to mention, and both men and women are quite expert in this work. The children attending Shubenacadie are not given this training. Therefore, they will have absolutely no means of making a living when they return to their homes, but will have to depend on their parents and the Department to assist them. I am of the opinion that this is a matter that needs careful consideration, as the book-learning they receive at school will not make them any more efficient to earn their living than the others.

I shall discuss this matter fully with Mr. Hoey, and I am sure the Principal and his staff will cooperate in any endeavour which will be of benefit to the boys and girls attending the Shubenacadie School.

General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, June 14, 1937.

Rev. Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a report from Mr. M. Christianson, General Superintendent of Indian Agencies, with reference to his recent visit to the Shubenacadie Indian Residential School.

Mr. Christianson was favourably impressed with general conditions at the school. However, he feels that, in view of conditions that now exist among the Indians in Nova Scotia, it is advisable to encourage more vocational training for both boys and girls.

I feel certain that you and the other members of the staff will cooperate with the Department in this regard. It is difficult, however, for us to decide exactly what should be done along these lines. I would appreciate receiving any recommendations in this connection that you care to make, and I can assure you that your proposals will receive sympathetic consideration,

Yours truly,

R. A. Hosey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Reverend Sir:

A complaint has been received that no Indians are employed in a capacity at the Shubenacadie Indian residential school. I realize that this is unfair criticism due to the fact that the Department is fully aware of the manner in which the lay staff of the school was selected. At the same time I felt it was advisable to bring the matter to your attention in order that you may make whatever comments you consider advisable.

I know that this involves extra equipment and possibly an additional member on the staff and while our funds are limited we are prepared to assist at least as far as money available will permit. As a matter of fact it is neither necessary nor advisable to install expensive equipment as very valuable training can be given with a comparatively small outlay of funds.

I shall await your report with interest.
