Dear Sir:-

In reply to your letter, with regard to "that no Indians are employed in any capacity at the Indian Residential School." The school was opened for pupils in February, 1930. From among all the pupils in attendance since that date to the present time, we have recently and most recently approved from the Department of Indian Affairs that one girl go on for higher education. This girl, Elsie Charles, is now a qualified teacher for this province. Two years ago there was an opening in an Indian day school. We recommended at the time that the girl be given this school. The Agent of the district was very much opposed to such procedure, saying emphatically that he had tried Indian teachers on previous occasions and found either that they were no good, or that the Indians themselves refused to co-operate in the least. At that time we thought the matter over thoroughly of employing the girl as a last resort at the school here. After we had considered the matter, we came to the conclusion that it would not work out to the advantage of anyone.

This may be the matter to which you have reference in your letter. Had you let us know the source of the complaint, and the exact matter complained about, we would be in a much better position to reply definitely. As it is we will cover as much ground as we think necessary, but even at that, we may be far astray from the point.

As for the men employed, three on full time, and the night fireman, for about five months out of the year. They are the farmer, assistant farmer, and carpenter-engineer. These men have been employed since 1929-1930 and have given satisfactory service. As for extra labor, in all building operations, there has been no extra labor, except for plasterers and electricians. Until this last summer we have done all farm work without any extra help. But this last year we had very few big boys here during haying time, and haying work was delayed on account of rainy weather. The situation as far as the hay was concerned was getting serious, and so we decided that as soon as the weather cleared, we would hire two extra men and rush the operation. Our own male staff worked sixteen hours a day, and the hired help ten to thirteen hours a day. One of the hired men was Al Gass who has been employed on the staff as night fireman for the past few years, so we really hired only one extra man. No kind of no Indian who in any way could take the place of any of our regular staff, and at the time we required the extra labor, most of the Indians capable of doing the work, were on the road making their way to Maine for picking potatoes.
We may have missed the point in the complaint made to you, but we think that we have covered fairly well the matter of the staff and the question of extra labor.

As for the vocational training, or manual training - as we understand it, that would mean all work other than reading, writing and arithmetic done in the class room. We will try and cover that in a general sort of way and enclose with this letter our schedule of work outside the regular class room.

At the opening of school in September, we make a list of the older boys, usually numbering from twenty to thirty boys, divide them into teams of five or six, mixing up the experienced with the inexperienced, having each team as nearly equal to the other as possible. A copy of the team list is posted in the dairy recreation room, and we hang it up in the office. Their duties are the barn chores and milking, morning and evening for one week at a time. It usually works out to be about ten weeks for each team. If the farm work calls for boys, we usually try to use these same boys who are on for milking duty. It sometimes happens that in one team of five or six boys, that two or three may be in different classes in school and sometimes different rooms. So in that case we try to have boys of the same class out of school at the same time. In the early fall when the root crop is gathered in, there would be twelve to twenty of the bigger boys out of the classroom until this work is cleared up. Then of course there are days and weeks when not more than one or two boys would be employed at farm work during the time when classes are held. In the spring, for the planting, the same applies as for the fall. As you well know, a good part of the farm work is done during July and August when so many of the older boys, because they have reached the age for discharge, are not here. Also so many more have gone hom for vacation. So there are only a few boys who get the in-between work, that is, between the planting and harvesting. Again, as you would expect, we have the boy who has reached the age of fourteen, and yet is small of stature and not a strong constitution, and therefore, it cannot be expected that he would take his turn at the heavier work. These are usually employed around the house, from taking meals to those who may be sick, to washing dishes and cleaning up refectory, recreation, toilet, and wash rooms. We feel that every child capable of work should be impressed with the idea that if they are to get along, they must work.

As for the manual training - from the time the school opened, we have built two dwelling houses, a hog house about seventy-five feet long by eighteen wide, a dairy and ice house, about 18 x 32, an addition to the feed room. As we have said before the only outdoor work we had for these buildings were for plastering and electric wiring, and the exception for excavation and cement work of one house. At that time we had very few big boys. All the bigger boys had their share in the work of erecting those buildings, from beginning to end, and the ones who were anxious to learn, did learn, but what can anyone do with a boy who does not want to learn.
Again, as far as work in the school is concerned, we had outside painters in for the painting in the Chapel, but our carpenter-engineer and the boys worked under their instructions. Our carpenter-engineer learned something from that job, as can be seen from the painting done since that time in the class rooms, sewing rooms, and other rooms in the house. All the bigger boys, of course, help with the painting. All repairs, replacing window frames, glass, etc., is done with the help of the boys, which, by the way, is a very practical thing for an Indian to learn. All our sleds, twenty double runners were made here, but we could not have the runners, bunks, bunks and beams because we have no band. The painting and keeping in repair these sleds during the skating season makes up quite a bit of work, and naturally the boys use the hammer, saw, screwdriver, wrench, etc., at this work. We don't know whether or not you noticed it, but we have had no outside help for plumbing and heating. We have had considerable work with leaky pipes, clogged drains, and many necessary replacements here and there. This work has been done by the carpenter-engineer and the boys. There are many more things along this same line which I should mention, but we don't think that is necessary. With the equipment we have, we think, that all things considered, these boys have an opportunity to learn many things which should stand them in good stead at a future time.

It is true that we do not make a particular drive at making baskets and axe handles. The market for these things in this locality is over supplied, and if we can teach the boys here to do some of the things that the boys on the reserve do not do, then we are bettering our own chances, and leaving the market for baskets, etc., to those who need it most. Again, these boys are only sixteen years of age when they leave here, and if they want to learn basket making for a living, it is not too late. During the two months they are home for vacation, they learn the business, because we have no trouble in getting baskets and other things made for our own use here.

In the manual training room, we have a harness sewing machine, a boot and shoe sewing machine, a boot repairer stand, and part of a lathe which we picked up at the Navy Yard in Halifax. All out foot wear is repaired here, and the boys have the opportunity of learning. The lathe or part of the lathe which we have, we use for repairing chairs, etc., turning rungs, etc. The tools used in turning out this wood work are borrowed and have been used here for the past few years. The boys see this work done but do not actually do the finer part of the work, because the fixtures are such that one has to be most careful and it is not safe enough to cover their carelessness.

We have been told by one who has had charge of an Indian School for nearly twenty years, that this school is in excellent condition, and better than some which were built about the same time. We don't know whether this is true or not, because we have only had the opportunity of visiting one other Indian Residential School and that only for a short time. However, the day may come soon when we will be given the opportunity of visiting some of the long established schools and learn from them how we can improve matters here.
We are getting tired of writing this, and no doubt you are weary from reading it. Nevertheless, we are going on to the work of the girls and follow that with some suggestions which may or may not be practical.

As with the boys, so with the girls. At the beginning of the school term we make a list of the bigger girls, placing the few who have been here during the summer at the bottom of the list. During the regular work, four girls and two Sisters are in the kitchen. Each week one girl leaves and another goes in, so that each girl has one month of kitchen work. For the girl going to the kitchen for the first time, her work does not require much experience, but by the end of the month, she will, if she wants to, have learned a good deal. The list is not so long but that each girl will have two turns during the school term. During the time preserving, two or more girls with experience are employed at the work. The girl leaving the kitchen, comes to my dining room, with a Sister present. She is taught how to set the table, and serve the meal. Entering the kitchen, say, two years before leaving the school, we feel that each girl, again if she wants to learn, can gain valuable experience. As would be expected we have to consider the girl who is small for her age, and not strong enough for the work. The laundry work works out quite regularly. The mending and darning, and there is plenty of that, is done by whole classes at a time. The new work in sewing blouses, middies, skirts and pants, requiring the use of sewing machines is done mostly by the same girls, who are on the list for kitchen work. To this is added knitting for both boys and girls, so that all mittens and winter stockings are made here. Again there is what we call the fancy work, hem stitching, tatting, crocheting, cut-work, mat hooking and quilting. In the Spring of each year we get the patterns of five or six dresses. The girls who are leading toward June, pick their pattern, do the cutting and sewing, in order to make the dress to suit and fit themselves. These dresses are then their own property to wear or take home with them. With the mats and quilts, we hold a drawing to decide who should have them.

By the time we have ball playing, coasting, skating, and keeping the house clean, the day is pretty well used up, and what is left we want for sleep. We are enclosing a copy of the list for kitchen, sewing, mending and laundry, showing the days on which this work is done.

Now for our suggestions. We have for the boys about what could be called an average carpenter outfit, together with the harness sewing machine, boot and shoe sewing machine and repair outfit, and an electric drill. We are enclosing a blue print of a small manual training outfit. We are sorry that it comes from the U.S.A., but if any of the longer established schools have a regular manual training outfit, it would be similar to this. With the outfit, we could make all sorts of furniture. While our own carpenter does not hold any diploma for manual training work, we feel certain that with a book to guide him, he could make an excellent showing at the work. Give him a picture, not a blue print of anything in furniture, and he will make it. So the matter of add-
ing to the staff for that work would not be necessary.

Although it may be necessary to hire someone to do the farm work which he under the present circumstances does. We have no idea of what this outfit would cost but before this letter is finished it may be possible that we can get this information. With this outfit and the necessary constructive and repair work on the building, well, to be honest about it, we feel that these boys would have many advantages over the average white boy. We would not say that out loud, but nevertheless, that is what we think about it.

As for the girls, if we had the woods, where we could have the boys obtain the material for baskets, that work could be undertaken in opposition to what is being done by the Indians on the Reserves.

For the past two years with the attendance up to and sometimes over 160, we consider that it is asking too much of any woman to supervise eighty children, running in ages from six to sixteen. So this year we are going to apply for two more Sisters, bringing the staff of Sisters up to twelve. For the assistant principal and the girls, we hope to have a domestic Science teacher who on at least two afternoons of each week, will be able to take a class of girls and provide a system whereby each girl will do her own cooking, etc., from beginning to end.

This is the last suggestion but we do not think it the least valuable. It is the matter of teaching as far as possible, first-aid. With the cooperation of the Doctor and the assistance of a registered nurse, and a book or two, we ought to be able to teach the more ambitious ones, something that would be helpful to them and perhaps others.

We hope that we have given you the information you have asked for, and that you will find out suggestions not too fantastic.

Yours very truly,

INDIAN BOYS AND GIRLS GET VALUABLE TRAINING AT SCHOOL AT SHUBENACADIE

WINCHESTER, March 1. — Our school boys and girls were hanging out their clothes to dry when they heard about something that was going to happen in their town. They were very excited when they heard that the Indian Residential School was being built.

MODERN BUILDING

The Shubenacadie Indian Residential School is now being constructed. It will be completed by next year. The school was opened in 1930 for boys and girls between the ages of 6 and 18.

Farming and manual training supplement the academic curriculum. For the boys, farming and woodworking are emphasized; for the girls, sewing and dressmaking are taught. A special class is offered for those who want to learn more about farming.

INTELLIGENTLY RUN

"We don't know whether we are doing enough," said Father MacKay, the principal. "We need more teachers and more facilities. We are doing our best, but we need more help."

Dear Madam:

A letter has just been received from the Director of Publicity for the Province of Nova Scotia in which he states that he has received a letter from you requesting information regarding the Indians near Shubenacadie, Nova Scotia.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of May 18th, concerning the hospital expenses for Christina Nicholas.

On Monday, December 2nd, 1941, a rather cold morning, this girl went, with others to the laundry. As far as we can find out, she warmed her hands on the mangle, and remarked that she was nearly caught. The next time she warmed her hands, she was caught. We immediately called Doctor MacInnis, and after doing some bandaging, he ordered her to the hospital. The hospital did not send us any account of her injuries. They may have supplied Dr. MacInnis with this information. Month followed month, and there was no sign of her coming home. She was seen by Sisters of the school at different times, and quite often by the former Superior of the Sisters here, who is now living in Halifax. We were all puzzled by the length of time it was taking to heal the hand. She returned to the school April 27th, with the hand bandaged, and the fingers still quite stiff, and bent towards the palm of the hand. While she was at the hospital we heard about the Doctors being quite annoyed because she would not exercise the hand, and also, that a certain amount of experimentation was being tried out. All this is just hearsay, so take it that way.

Since returning to the school, she has improved generally, and by doing some crochet work, she is getting movement in the fingers, and is now able to take a grip with the hand.

She is due back at the hospital May 27th, and we hope that they will be satisfied with the progress made.

Yours very truly,

MONTHLY REPORT FOR NOVEMBER 1942

On November I went to Tyne Valley, on November 11 visited Lennox Island, found our building program progressing favourably expect to have those houses completed by the end of the month. Accompanied by Father Murphy, we visited all the homes on the Island, paid the help for picking potatoes, made arrangements for distributing some of the potatoes to those Indians who are in need.

On November 17, I again visited Lennox Island, arranged with Mr. Gillis, our Foreman to procure more help to have our building program speeded up, on the 19th accompanied by Father Murphy, we visited the residential school at Subansacadi, as I wanted to see the Indian children from our reserve here who are going to the school. Accompanied by Father Mackey, we visited the Indian reserve at Subansacadi, and may say that I was very much impressed by the general set up and feel my visit to both the school and the reserve there will be of great value to our centralization plan here.

Respectfully Yours,
J.E. Daly

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter concerning the fact that Stewart Cooper left his work here, and the matter of hiring Charles Crowell.

Mr. Cooper came here in 1929, and gave satisfaction for a number of years. However, for the past few years he had told me that he was going to leave, as he felt that he needed more money. I did not offer any more money, as I felt that throughout the years, he had been treated very well. So when he had the opportunity to get on the Railroad, he decided to go. That was January first of this year. We thought that we could get along with the assistant farmer, Lawrence Parker, until the Spring work would begin. We did not inform the Department about Cooper leaving, because in the past, we have been told what person to hire.

As for Charles Crowell, age about thirty one, married, and has worked on different farms in this vicinity for years. He is an experienced truck driver, and we hope will be a good operator for the tractor. Cooper never did learn to operate the tractor. We think that, locally, at least, he was the best man available, and as far as we know, should be acceptable to a certain individual; not that it would make a particle of difference to us, if it were otherwise.

Needless to say, Lawrence Parker will be the head farmer, taking Cooper's place and pay, and Crowell will be the Assistant.

SUMMARY OF ACTIVITIES AT THE SHUBENACADIE INDIAN AGENCY FROM OCTOBER - 43 TO JANUARY - 44.

On December 14th this centralization project lost, to a great extent, the services of a good friend and an experienced adviser, Rev. Fr. Mackie, principal of the Residential School since its founding, was forced by recurring illnesses to relinquish his place as Principal and revert again to light parish work. Practically all summer his stomach condition bothered him and was aggravated, I believe, by a series of regrettable occurrences. First blow was the accidental drowning of two young girls of the school. He felt this very keenly. Next came an epidemic of diphtheria at the school, then three runaway attempts in extremely cold weather by children who were ill clothed for the temperatures we were then experiencing. Finally just home from the hospital he was unfortunate enough to meet the doctor, on the doorstep of the school, coming out with a child on a stretcher. The idea which had been milling in his mind for some time suddenly became a decision and he forthwith sent in his resignation. We here at the agency and all of Shubenacadie were sorry to see him go, but we feel that due to his health the step he took was necessary. It is well known that the work of the present successor or any other in fact, will be made much easier because of the good will and respect enjoyed in this community by Fr. Mackie.

His successor, Fr. Brown, was my parish priest in Kentville and served for a time in Enfield 14 miles from here. His knowledge of the Cambridge Indians is extensive and it is well known that he always had a liking for what he calls "the poor Indian". He is a favourite of all children regardless of color or creed and in my opinion will have more trouble with ration coupons and pedigrees than managing 160 children. He too is a backer of the centralization idea and will do all in his power to help and speed the project along.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Re: Shubenacadie Indian Residential School

I inspected this school very carefully on September 7 and found everything running smoothly.

I must point out, however, that the Principal, Reverend Father J.W. Brown, is 64 years of age and, while he is quite vigorous, at the same time it is evident that the smooth operation is depending, to a large extent, upon the Reverend Sisters. During the course of an interview with Most Reverend J.T. McHale, Archbishop of Halifax, on September 5, I pointed out to him that, while we realize the difficulty of securing young men at the present time, owing to the number of priests from this diocese in the Armed Forces, at the same time the Department hopes that conditions will make it possible for a young man to be secured in the near future.

The pottery programme is proceeding very satisfactorily and a number of articles are being sold to people who call at the school. The Principal of the Province of Nova Scotia Technical College, at which pottery is taught visits Shubenacadie frequently and is extremely interested in the work that is being done at the school. Due to the fact that several of the pupils who make pottery will eventually reside on the Shubenacadie Reserve, it is quite likely that this industry could be further encouraged on the reserve when the Sisters take charge of the day school. It is understood that one of the teachers who will go to the Shubenacadie Day School eventually will be able to continue the pottery training.

You will recall that there was some correspondence regarding the purchase of additional land for the school and at the time the request was made to us we expressed the opinion that no additional land should be secured at the present time. I discussed this matter with the former Principal, Reverend J.F. Mackey, whom I met in Halifax on September 6, and he stated that there was approximately ten acres of land adjacent to the school which could be desirable to purchase at such time, but that, as the school has done very well with the amount of land they have, he did not see any particular reason for making the purchase at the present time, other than it might stop anyone else from securing it. In discussing the matter further with Father Brown it appears that he has lately purchased five acres of this ten-acre plot. Evidently, following our refusal to purchase land, he purchased the five acres from his own funds. He paid $100 an acre for it, or a total of $500. He stated that...
if the Department wished to secure this from him at any time he was quite willing to transfer title to us for the amount just stated.

There is a continuation school in the village of Shubenacadie, which is situated about a mile from the school where instruction is given as far as Grade II. Pupils who take Grade II in the Nova Scotia schools can then proceed to Normal School for a year's training and obtain a teacher's certificate. A few years ago one of the pupils of the Shubenacadie School, James Prosper, resided at the Shubenacadie Residential School and took Grade II at the village school. He is now in the Air Force.

It is interesting to know that 55 former pupils of the Shubenacadie Residential School are now in the Canadian Army. Of these 3 have been killed. One, Jimmy Foster mentioned above, is in the Air Force and 2 ex-pupils are in the United States Navy.

Both the main building and the outbuildings are in good condition, with the exception of the trouble that they have been having with the wall. Mr. Sparks of the Survey Engineering Branch who has been at Shubenacadie in connection with the erection of the new day school, made a careful inspection of the wall and roof and it is his opinion that the coping at the top of the walls should be fixed. He claims that if this is done the leaking of water into the building will be prevented. He had representatives of two firms inspect the roof with him and their quotations have not yet been received, but he estimated the expenditure would probably amount to $2000.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

This note tells of the death of our Mr. Edward McLeod, who has been in charge of general repairs for everything from book to roof, since the school was opened.

His acute illness came on following the water pipe breakdown last fall. A "Kidney Infection" was the ailment, as reported from the Halifax Infirmary, where he spent some six weeks and lived only three weeks following his return from the hospital. May I inquire if any Departmental consideration is given for the grave illness, hospital or funeral costs, of a faithful servant of many years standing?

I do not know what the Department procedure is, in his replacement.

Mr. L. Parker, our farmer, would quit the management of the farm, and take over the Engineer work and repairs. He is a very handy man, had helped Mr. McLeod over the years, knows steam boilers, pumps, and electrical set-up around the building and barns. I think he would care for the work well. If the Department accepts the suggestion, it would be satisfactory to me. Mr. Parker suggested the change himself.

Mr. Growell, Assistant farmer, advised me recently that he is giving up his work on April 15th. He has had a lot of illness since last November, and feels he might not be strong enough to carry on the Spring and Summer work.
Indian Residential School

I feel sure I can secure the services of a good farmer; he may have to be a Veteran of the First War. I need not insist that these positions need not have to do with Local Politicians, nor even returned men. If I have any Political inquiries, much more appointments, my reply will be "The Department will make the appointments" and no one goes to work without my direction; I sign the Department checks.

I have asked Rev. Dr. MacPherson, Agricultural Director at Antigonish, to find a suitable assistant farmer, and now I will have him interview a prospective farmer to assume management of the farm and stock. He must be an "Ayrshire" expert.

Reports from our field officials indicate that Father Brown's health is not as good as it should be for one in such a responsible position. He is now over sixty-five years of age. Changes in the Civil Service Superannuation Act are such that only under very special and extenuating circumstances are we permitted to retain as civil servants anyone over the age of sixty-five. While these regulations do not apply naturally to such positions as principals of these schools, nevertheless, it is felt that where possible we should conform with this policy.

We realize that Father Brown has done very fine work at this school in the past. Our officials all agree that no one could show a more fatherly interest in the Indians. He has endeared himself to these people and has always been their champion.

However, we feel that in the interests of the school administration and of the children therein, you should consider replacing him with a younger man. We fully appreciate the shortage of Priests and the difficulties

We have your letter of the 23rd ultimo with reference to Beatrice E. Paul and the complaint of Mrs. Mary E. North.

While we realize that the Indian children at the Shubenacadie School are receiving every possible care and attention, at the same time we are slightly disturbed at the statement in your letter "when this girl became eligible for discharge the responsibility of welfare was accepted by her father, James S. Paul (no permanent place of abode)".

The return for the quarter ended June 30th, 1947 stated that this girl was 16 years of age and we feel that before placing her in charge of her father who had no permanent place of abode, the Department should have been consulted. In this connection I would refer you to the latter part of Section 10 of the Indian Act which reads as follows:

"Provided that where it has been made to appear to the satisfaction of the Superintendent General (Minister) that it would be detrimental to any particular Indian child to have it discharged from school on attaining the full age of sixteen years, the Superintendent General (Minister) may direct that such child be detained at school for such further period as may seem to be advisable but not beyond the full age of eighteen years."
This part of Section 10 refers to cases such as the one under discussion and we feel that the management should be advised that in future they should keep this part of Section 10 in mind when pupils are being discharged, especially girls.

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.
